text: On the fifth day of the fourth month in the thirtieth year, while I was living among the exiles by the Chebar River, the sky opened, and I saw visions from God.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fifth day of the month, during the fifth year of the exile of King Jehoiakin,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord spoke his word to the priest Ezekiel, son of Buzi, in Babylon by the Chebar River. The power of the Lord came over Ezekiel.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I looked, I saw a storm coming from the north. There was an immense cloud with flashing lightning surrounded by a bright light. The middle of the lightning looked like glowing metal.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the center of the cloud I saw what looked like four living creatures. They were shaped like humans,
speaker: Narrator

text: but each of them had four faces and four wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their legs were straight, their feet were like those of calves, and they glittered like polished bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had human hands under their wings on each of their four sides. All four of them had faces and wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their wings touched each other. The creatures went straight ahead, and they did not turn as they moved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their faces looked like this: From the front, each creature had the face of a human. From the right, each one had the face of a lion. From the left, each one had the face of a bull. And from the back, each one had the face of an eagle.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is what their faces looked like. Their wings were spread out, pointing upward. Each creature had two wings with which they touched each other. The other two wings covered their bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of the creatures went straight ahead. They went wherever their spirit wanted to go, and they didn’t turn as they moved.
speaker: Narrator

text: The living creatures looked like burning coals and torches. Fire moved back and forth between the living creatures. The fire was bright, and lightning came out of the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The living creatures ran back and forth like lightning.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I looked at the living creatures, I saw a wheel on the ground beside each of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how the wheels looked and how they were made: They looked like beryl. All four wheels looked the same. They looked like a wheel within a wheel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever they moved, they moved in any of the four directions without turning as they moved.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rims of the wheels were large and frightening. They were covered with eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the living creatures moved, the wheels moved with them. When the living creatures rose from the earth, the wheels rose.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever their spirit wanted to go, the creatures went. The wheels rose with them, because the spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels.
speaker: Narrator

text: So whenever the creatures moved, the wheels moved. Whenever the creatures stood still, the wheels stood still. And whenever the creatures rose from the earth, the wheels rose with them, because the spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Something like a dome was spread over the heads of the living creatures. It looked like dazzling crystal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Under the dome, each creature had two wings that were stretched out straight, touching one another. Each creature had two wings that covered its body.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the creatures moved, I heard the sound of their wings. The sound was like the noise of rushing water, like the thunder of the Almighty, like the commotion in an army camp. When the creatures stood still, they lowered their wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: A voice came from above the dome over their heads as they stood still with their wings lowered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above the dome over their heads was something that looked like a throne made of sapphire. On the throne was a figure that looked like a human.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I saw what he looked like from the waist up. He looked like glowing bronze with fire all around it. From the waist down, he looked like fire. A bright light surrounded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The brightness all around him looked like a rainbow in the clouds. It was like the Lord’s glory. When I saw it, I immediately bowed down, and I heard someone speaking.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, stand up, and I will speak to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As he spoke to me, the Spirit entered me, stood me on my feet, and I heard him speaking to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, I am sending you to the people of Israel. They are people from a nation that has rebelled against me. They and their ancestors have rebelled against me to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am sending you to these defiant and stubborn children. Tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Whether these rebellious people listen or not, they will realize that a prophet has been among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, don’t be afraid of them or the things they say. Don’t be afraid, even though thorns and thistles are around you and you live among scorpions. Don’t let the things they say frighten you. Don’t be terrified in their presence, even though they are rebellious people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Speak my words to them whether they listen or not, because they are rebellious.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you, son of man, listen to what I say. Don’t be rebellious like those rebellious people. Open your mouth, and eat what I am giving to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As I looked, I saw a hand stretched out toward me. In it was a scroll.
speaker: Narrator

text: He spread the scroll in front of me. There was writing on the front and back. There were funeral songs, songs of mourning, and horrible things written on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to me, “Son of man, eat what you find. Eat this scroll. Then speak to the people of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I opened my mouth, and he gave me the scroll to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, eat this scroll I’m giving you, and fill your stomach with it.” So I ate it, and it tasted as sweet as honey in my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, go to the people of Israel, and speak my words to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not sending you to people whose language is hard to understand or difficult to speak. I am sending you to Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not sending you to nations whose language is hard to understand, difficult to speak, or whose words you cannot understand. If I send you to those nations, they will certainly listen to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people of Israel will refuse to listen to you because they refuse to listen to me. All the people of Israel are very stubborn and hardheaded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet, I will make you as stubborn and as hardheaded as they are.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make you as hard as a diamond, harder than stone. Don’t be afraid of them. Don’t be terrified in their presence, even though they are rebellious people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He also said to me, “Son of man, take to heart everything I have spoken to you, and listen closely.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to the exiles, to your people. Whether they listen or not, tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit lifted me, and behind me I heard a loud thundering voice say, “Blessed is the Lord’s glory, which left this place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I also heard the noise of the wings of the living creatures touching one another and the noise of the wheels beside them as well as a loud rumbling.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit lifted me and took me away. I went away feeling bitter and angry. The strong power of the Lord came over me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I went to Tel Abib, to the exiles who lived by the Chebar River. I sat there among them for seven days. I was stunned.
speaker: Narrator

text: After seven days the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, I have made you a watchman over the people of Israel. Listen to what I say, and warn them for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose I tell you that wicked people will surely die, but you don’t warn them or speak out so that they can change their wicked ways in order to save their lives. Then these wicked people will die because of their sin, but I will hold you responsible for their deaths.
speaker: Narrator

text: But suppose you warn the wicked people, and they don’t turn from their wicked ways. Then they will die because of their sin, but you will save yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: If righteous people turn from living the right way and do wrong, I will make them stumble, and they will die. If you don’t warn them, they will die because of their sin, and the right things they did will not be remembered. I will hold you responsible for their deaths.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you warn righteous people not to sin, and they don’t sin, they will certainly live because they listened to the warning. You will save yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The power of the Lord came over me. He said, “Get up, and go to the plain. I will speak to you there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I got up and went to the plain. The Lord’s glory was standing there like the glory I saw by the Chebar River, and I immediately bowed down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit entered me and stood me on my feet. He talked to me. He said, “Go into your home, and shut yourself inside.
speaker: Narrator

text: People will tie you up with ropes, son of man, so that you can’t go outside.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make your tongue stick to the roof of your mouth so that you can’t talk or criticize them, even though they are rebellious people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when I speak to you, I will open your mouth. You will tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says.’ Some will listen, and some will refuse to listen. They are rebellious people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “Son of man, take clay, put it in front of you, and draw a map of Jerusalem on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Set up a blockade against it, build attack walls around it, put up dirt ramps around it, have troops ready to attack it, and place battering rams all around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then take an iron pan, and set it up as a wall between you and the city. Turn your face toward the city as if you were going to attack it, and then attack it. This is a sign for the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then lie on your left side and take the punishment of the nation of Israel yourself. You will bear its punishment as many days as you lie on that side.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have assigned to you one day for each year its punishment will last. So for 390 days, you will bear the punishment for the sins of the nation of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you finish this, you will lie down again, this time on your right side. You will bear the punishment for the sins of the nation of Judah for 40 days, one day for each year I have assigned to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Turn your face toward the blockaded Jerusalem. Shake your fist and prophesy against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will tie you up with ropes so that you will not be able to turn from one side to the other until you have finished attacking Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then take wheat, barley, beans, lentils, millet, and winter wheat. Put them in a container, and use them to make bread for yourself. Eat it during the 390 days that you are lying on your side.
speaker: Narrator

text: The food that you eat should be weighed. Eat eight ounces of food every day at set times.
speaker: Narrator

text: Measure out two-thirds of a quart of water, and drink it at set times.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat the bread as you would eat barley loaves. Bake the bread in front of people, using human excrement for fuel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “In the same way, the people of Israel will eat unclean  bread among the nations where I scatter them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I answered, “Almighty Lord, I have never dishonored myself. From the time I was young until now, I have never eaten an animal that died by itself or was killed by other wild animals. No unclean meat has ever entered my mouth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “I will let you use cow manure in place of human excrement. Bake your bread over it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He also said to me, “Son of man, I am going to cut off the bread supply in Jerusalem. People will anxiously eat rationed bread and fearfully drink rationed water.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will be shocked at the sight of each other because of the lack of food and water. They will waste away because of their sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “Son of man, take a sharp blade, and use it as a barber’s razor to shave your head and beard. Take scales to weigh your hair and divide it into three even parts.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the blockade is over, burn one-third of your hair in a fire in the middle of the city. Take another third, and cut it up with a blade around the city. Then scatter the remaining third to the wind, and I will draw a sword and go after it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take a few strands of hair, and wrap them in the hem of your clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, take some of them, and throw them in a fire and burn them up. From there a fire will spread throughout the whole nation of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Almighty Lord says: This is Jerusalem! I have placed it in the center of the nations with countries all around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Jerusalem have rebelled against my rules and my laws more than the surrounding nations. They have rejected my rules, and they don’t live by my laws.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So this is what the Almighty Lord says: People of Jerusalem, you have caused more trouble than the nations around you. You haven’t lived by my laws or obeyed my rules. You haven’t even lived up to the standards of the nations around you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So this is what the Almighty Lord says: I, too, am against you, and I will punish you in front of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of all the detestable things that you do, I will do things to you that I have never done before and will never do again.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why parents will eat their children, and children will eat their parents. I will punish you and scatter whoever is left to the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As I live, declares the Almighty Lord, because you have dishonored my holy worship place with all your disgusting and detestable things, I will have you killed. I will not have compassion for you or feel sorry for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: One-third of you will die in plagues and be devoured in famines. Another third will die in battles against those around you. I will scatter the remaining third to the wind, and I will pursue them with a sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will unleash my anger. I will use my fury against you, and I will get revenge. When my fury is unleashed against you, you will know that I, the Lord, spoke to you while I was angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn you into a wasteland and an object of ridicule among the nations around you and in the presence of everyone who passes by you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The nations that are around you will ridicule you and laugh at you. When I punish you because of my anger, fury, and fierce revenge, you will become something ridiculed and something horrible. I, the Lord, have spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I shoot my destructive arrows of famine at you, I will shoot to kill you. I will bring more and more famines into your land, and I will cut off your food supply.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send famines and wild animals against you, and they will rob you of your children. I will send plagues, violence, and wars to kill you. I, the Lord, have spoken.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, look toward the mountains of Israel, and prophesy against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say this, ‘You mountains of Israel, listen to the Almighty Lord’s word! This is what the Almighty Lord says to the mountains and hills and to the ravines and valleys: I am going to attack you with a sword and destroy your worship sites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your altars will be destroyed, and your incense burners will be smashed. I will kill people in front of your idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will lay the dead bodies of the people of Israel in front of your idols, and I will scatter their bones around your altars.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever people live, the cities will be ruined, and the worship sites will be wrecked. Your altars will be ruined and demolished. Your idols will be smashed and completely destroyed. Your incense burners will be cut down, and everything you have done will be wiped out.
speaker: Narrator

text: People will be killed, and they will fall among you. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘But I will let some people live. Some people will escape the battle among the nations and be scattered throughout the countries.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then those who escape will remember me among the nations where they are taken captive. I was hurt by their adulterous hearts, which turned away from me, and by their eyes, which lusted after idols. They will hate themselves for the evil and disgusting things that they have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know that I am the Lord and that the disaster I promised was not an empty threat.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Clap your hands, stomp your feet, and say, “Oh no!” because the people of Israel have done evil and disgusting things. So they will die in wars, famines, and plagues.
speaker: Narrator

text: Plagues will kill those who are far away. Those who are near will die in wars, and anyone who is left and has escaped will die in famines. This is how I will unleash my anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will know that I am the Lord.
“ ‘Those who are killed will lie beside the idols around their altars. They will lie on every high hill, on all the mountaintops, and under every large tree and every leafy oak. These are the places where they made offerings to their disgusting idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will use my power against them and destroy the land, from the desert to Diblah. Then they will know that I am the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, this is what the Almighty Lord says to the people in the land of Israel: The end is coming! The end is coming to the four corners of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the end is coming for you. I will send my anger against you. I will judge you for the way you have lived, and I will punish you for all the detestable things that you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will not have compassion for you or feel sorry for you. I will pay you back for the way you have lived and for the detestable things you have done. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Almighty Lord says: One disaster after another is coming.
speaker: Narrator

text: The end is coming. The end is coming. It is stirring itself up against you. It is coming!
speaker: Narrator

text: Destruction is coming to you, inhabitants of the land. The time is coming. The day is near. There will be confusion. There will be no joy in the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon I will pour out my fury on you and unleash my anger on you. I will judge you for the way you have lived, and I will punish you for all the detestable things that you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will not have compassion or feel sorry. I will pay you back for the way you have lived and for the detestable things that you are still doing. Then you will know that I am the Lord and that I am the one attacking you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The day is near! It is coming! Destruction is coming! Wrongdoing has blossomed. Arrogance has flourished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Violence has grown into a weapon for punishing wickedness. None of the people will be left. None of that crowd, none of their wealth, and nothing of value will be left.
speaker: Narrator

text: The time is coming. The day is near. Buyers will not rejoice, and sellers will not mourn, because my fury will be against the whole crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sellers will not live long enough to buy back what they have sold. The visions against that crowd will not change. Because of their sins, none of the people will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have blown a ram’s horn, and everything is ready. But no one will go into battle, because my fury is against their whole crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Outside are swords, and inside are plagues and famines. Whoever is in a field will die in battle. Whoever is in the city will be devoured by famines and plagues.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who survive will escape to the mountains. They will moan like doves in the valleys. They will moan because of their sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every hand will hang limp, and every knee will be as weak as water.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will put on sackcloth, and horror will cover them. All their faces will be covered with shame, and every head will be shaved.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will throw their silver and gold into the streets like garbage. Their silver and gold won’t be able to rescue them on the day of the Lord’s anger. It will no longer satisfy their hunger or fill their stomachs. Their silver and gold caused them to fall into sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were proud of their beautiful jewels and used them to make disgusting and detestable statues of false gods. That is why I will make their jewels disgusting.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will hand their jewels over to foreigners as loot and to the most evil people on earth as prizes. These foreigners will dishonor the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn my face away from the people of Israel, and foreigners will dishonor my treasured place. Robbers will go in and dishonor it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Get the chains ready! The land is filled with murder, and the city is filled with violence.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I will send the most evil nation, and it will take possession of people’s houses. I will stop those who are strong from feeling proud, and their holy places will be dishonored.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anguish is coming. People will look for peace, but there will be none.
speaker: Narrator

text: One disaster will happen after another. One rumor will follow another. People will ask for a vision from a prophet. The teachings of priests and the advice of leaders will disappear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kings will mourn, and princes will give up hope. The common people will lose their courage. I will give them what they deserve and judge them as they have judged others. Then they will know that I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fifth day of the sixth month in the sixth year, I was sitting in my home. Judah’s leaders were sitting in front of me. The power of the Almighty Lord came over me.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I looked, I saw something that looked like a human. From the waist down its body looked like fire, and from the waist up its body looked like glowing metal.
speaker: Narrator

text: It stretched out what looked like a hand and grabbed me by the hair on my head. In these visions from God, the Spirit carried me between heaven and earth. He took me to Jerusalem, to the entrance to the north gate of the inner courtyard of the temple. That was where an idol that stirs up God’s anger was located.
speaker: Narrator

text: There I saw the glory of Israel’s God as I did in the vision that I saw in the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to me, “Son of man, look toward the north.” So I looked toward the north, and there in the entrance to the north gate beside the altar, I saw the idol that stirs up God’s anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked me, “Son of man, do you see what the people of Israel are doing? The people of Israel are doing very disgusting things here, things that will force me to go far away from my holy place. But you will see even more disgusting things.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took me to the entrance of the courtyard. As I looked, I saw a hole in the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, dig through the wall.” So I dug through the wall, and I saw a door.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Go in, and see the wicked, disgusting things that the people of Israel are doing here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I went in and looked. I saw that the walls were covered with drawings of every kind of crawling creature, every kind of disgusting animal, and all the idols in the nation of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In front of these drawings stood 70 of Israel’s leaders. Jaazaniah, son of Shaphan, was standing with the leaders. Each of them was holding an incense burner in his hand, and a cloud of incense went up.
speaker: Narrator

text: God asked me, “Son of man, do you see what the leaders of the nation of Israel are doing in secret? Each of them is in the room where his god is, and each one of them is thinking, ‘The Lord doesn’t see me. The Lord has abandoned this land.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me, “You will see even more disgusting things that they are doing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought me to the entrance of the north gate of the Lord’s temple. Women were sitting there and crying for the god Tammuz.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked me, “Son of man, do you see this? You will see even more disgusting things than these.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought me into the inner courtyard of the Lord’s temple. There at the entrance to the Lord’s temple, between the entrance and the altar, were about 25 men who had their backs turned to the Lord’s temple. They were facing east and worshiping the rising sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked me, “Son of man, do you see this? Isn’t it bad enough that the people of Judah have done these disgusting things that you have seen here? Yet, they also fill the land with violence and continue to provoke me even more. Look how they insult me in the worst possible way.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I will take action because I’m angry, and I won’t have compassion for them or feel sorry for them. Even if they shout in my ears, I won’t listen to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I heard the Lord call out with a loud voice. He said, “Come here, those who are going to punish this city. Each of you should bring your weapon with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So six men came from the upper north gate. Each one brought a deadly weapon with him. Among them was a person dressed in linen who was carrying paper and pen. The men came in and stood by the bronze altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the glory of the God of Israel went up from the angels, where it had been, to the temple’s entrance. The Lord called to the person dressed in linen who was carrying paper and pen.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to that person, “Go throughout the city of Jerusalem, and put a mark on the foreheads of those who sigh and groan about all the disgusting things that are being done in the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to the others as I was listening, “Follow him throughout the city and kill. Don’t have any compassion, and don’t feel sorry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kill old men, young men, old women, young women, and children. But don’t come near anyone who has a mark on him. Start with my holy place.” So they started with the old men in front of the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Dishonor the temple! Fill its courtyards with dead people, and then leave.” So they went out and killed the people in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were killing people, I was left alone. So I immediately bowed down. I cried, “Almighty Lord, will you destroy everyone who is left in Israel while you pour out your anger on Jerusalem?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered me, “The wickedness of the nations of Israel and Judah is terrible. The land is filled with murder, and the city is filled with wrongdoing. They think that the Lord has abandoned the land and that he doesn’t see.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will not have compassion or feel sorry. I will do to them what they have done to others.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the person dressed in linen who was carrying paper and pen reported, “I did everything you commanded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As I looked at the dome over the heads of the angels, I saw something that looked like a throne made of sapphire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to the person dressed in linen, “Go between the wheels under the angels, and fill your hands with burning coals. Then scatter them over the city.” So he went between the wheels as I watched.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angels were standing on the south side of the temple as the person went. A cloud filled the inner courtyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s glory rose from the angels to the entrance of the temple, the cloud filled the temple, and the brightness of the Lord’s glory filled the courtyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sound of the angels’ wings was heard as far as the outer courtyard. It was like the sound of the Almighty God when he speaks.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the Lord had commanded the person dressed in linen to take burning coals from between the wheels beside the angels, the person went in and stood beside one of the wheels.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of the angels reached into the fire that was between the angels and took out some coals. This angel put them in the hands of the person dressed in linen. The person took them and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angels appeared to have what looked like human hands under their wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I looked, I saw four wheels beside the angels, one wheel beside each of the angels. The wheels looked like beryl.
speaker: Narrator

text: All four wheels looked the same. Each was like a wheel within a wheel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the angels moved, they moved in any of the four directions without turning as they moved. They always moved in the direction they faced without turning as they moved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their entire bodies, their backs, hands, wings, and wheels were covered with eyes. Each of the angels had a wheel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I heard that the wheels were called the whirling wheels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of the angels had four faces. The first was the face of an angel, the second was the face of a human, the third was the face of a lion, and the fourth was the face of an eagle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angels rose. These were the living creatures that I saw at the Chebar River.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the angels moved, the wheels moved beside them. When the angels lifted their wings to rise from the ground, the wheels didn’t leave their side.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the angels stood still, the wheels stood still. When the angels rose, the wheels rose with them. The spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the glory of the Lord left the temple’s entrance and stood over the angels.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angels lifted their wings and rose from the ground. I was watching them as they left with the wheels beside them. The angels stood at the door to the east gate of the Lord’s temple, and the glory of the God of Israel was above them.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the living creatures that I saw under the God of Israel at the Chebar River. I realized that they were angels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each had four faces and four wings, and under their wings were what looked like human hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their faces looked exactly like the faces that I saw by the Chebar River. Each one went straight ahead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit lifted me and took me to the east gate of the Lord’s temple. (It’s the gate that faces east.) Twenty-five men were at the entrance of the gate. I saw among them Azzur’s son Jaazaniah and Benaiah’s son Pelatiah. They were leaders of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, “Son of man, these are the men who plan evil and give bad advice in this city.
speaker: Narrator

text: They say, ‘It’s almost time to rebuild homes. This city is a cooking pot, and we’re the meat.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So prophesy against them. Prophesy, son of man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s Spirit came to me and told me to say, “This is what the Lord says: You are saying these things, nation of Israel. But I know what’s going through your mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have killed many people in this city and have filled its streets with corpses.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So this is what the Almighty Lord says: The corpses that you put in the middle of the city are the meat, and the city is the cooking pot. I will force you out of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are afraid of swords, so I will bring swords to attack you, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will force you out of the city. I will hand you over to foreigners, and I will punish you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will die in battle. I will judge you at Israel’s borders. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The city will not be your cooking pot, and you will not be the meat in it. I will judge you at Israel’s borders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know that I am the Lord. You haven’t lived by my laws, and you haven’t obeyed my rules. You have followed the standards set by the nations around you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
While I was prophesying, Benaiah’s son Pelatiah died.
I immediately bowed down and cried out, “Almighty Lord, will you completely destroy all the remaining people in Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, the people who live in Jerusalem are talking about your own relatives and about the entire nation of Israel. The people who live in Jerusalem say, ‘They are far away from the Lord. This land has been given to us as our own property.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Although I sent them far away among the nations and scattered them among the countries, I have been their sanctuary for a little while among the countries where they’ve gone.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I will bring them together from the nations and gather them from the countries where I’ve scattered them. I will give them the land of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will come and remove all the disgusting and detestable things that are there.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give them a single purpose and put a new spirit in them. I will remove their stubborn hearts and give them obedient hearts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will live by my laws and obey my rules. They will be my people, and I will be their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for those whose minds are set on following detestable and disgusting idols, I will pay them back for what they have done, declares the Almighty Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angels  raised their wings, with the wheels beside them. The glory of the God of Israel was above them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s glory left the middle of the city and stopped above the mountain east of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this vision from God’s Spirit, the Spirit lifted me and brought me to the exiles in Babylonia. Then the vision I saw left me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I told the exiles everything the Lord had shown me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, you are living among rebellious people. They have eyes, but they can’t see. They have ears, but they can’t hear because they are rebellious people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, pack your bags as if you were going into exile. Let the people see you leave in the daylight. March like a captive from your place to another place as they watch. Maybe they will understand, even though they are rebellious people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them see you in the daylight. Bring out your bags as if you were going into exile. In the evening let them see you leave like a captive going into exile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dig a hole through the wall of your house, and leave through it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them see you put your bags on your shoulders and carry them out in the dark. Cover your face so that you won’t see the land. I’ve made you a sign to warn the nation of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I did what I was ordered to do. During the day I brought out bags as if I were going into exile. In the evening I dug a hole through the wall. I brought out my bags in the dark. I let the people see me as I carried my bags on my shoulders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, didn’t the rebellious nation of Israel ask you what you were doing?
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: This is the divine revelation about the prince from Jerusalem and about all the people of Israel who live there.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell them, ‘I am your warning sign. What I have done will happen to you. You will go into exile and into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prince who is among you will put his bags on his shoulders in the dark and leave. People will dig holes in the wall to go through. The prince will cover his face so that he cannot see the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will spread my net over him, and he will be caught in my net. I will bring him to Babylon, the land of the Babylonians, but he will not see it. And that’s where he’ll die.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will scatter in every direction all those who are around him—his staff and all his troops. I will pursue them with my sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will know that I am the Lord, because I will scatter them among the nations and force them into other countries.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, I will spare a few of them from wars, famines, and plagues. Wherever they go among the nations, they will realize that everything they did was disgusting. Then they will know that I am the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, shake as you eat your food. Tremble and be worried as you drink your water.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the people of this land, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says about the people who live in Jerusalem and in the land of Israel: They will be worried as they eat their food and terrified as they drink their water. Their country will be stripped of everything because everyone who lives there is violent.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cities where people live will be destroyed, and the country will become a wasteland. Then they will know that I am the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, what is this proverb you have in Israel: ‘Days go by, and every vision comes to nothing’?
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the people, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I will put a stop to the use of this proverb. You will no longer quote it in Israel.’ Instead, tell them, ‘The time is near when every vision will come true.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will no longer be any false visions or flattering fortunetelling to the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, the Lord, will speak. Everything that I say will happen without any more delay. I will say something, and it will happen during your lifetime, you rebellious people, declares the Almighty Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, the people of Israel are saying, ‘The vision that Ezekiel sees won’t happen for a long time. What he prophecies will happen in the distant future.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Everything that I say will no longer be delayed. Whatever I say will happen, declares the Almighty Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, prophesy against the prophets of Israel. Tell those who make up their prophecies, ‘Listen to the Lord’s word.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: How horrible it will be for the foolish prophets. They follow their own ideas, and they have seen nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel, your prophets are like foxes among the ruins of a city.
speaker: Narrator

text: They haven’t repaired the gaps in the wall or rebuilt the wall for the nation of Israel. So Israel will not be protected in battle on the day of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: These foolish prophets see false visions, and their predictions don’t come true. They say, “The Lord said this.” But the Lord hasn’t sent them. Then they hope that their message will come true.
speaker: Narrator

text: Prophets of Israel, haven’t you seen false visions and predicted things that don’t come true? Don’t you say, “The Lord said this,” even though I haven’t said anything?
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Your predictions are false, and your visions are lies. That is why I’m against you, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will use my power against the prophets who see false visions and predict things that don’t come true. They will not help my people make decisions or be recorded in the records of the nation of Israel. They won’t even enter Israel. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘They have deceived my people by saying that everything is alright, but it’s not alright. When someone builds a flimsy wall, the prophets cover it up with paint.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell those who cover up the wall with paint that their wall will fall down. Rain will pour down, hailstones will fall on it, and stormy winds will break it to pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the wall falls down, people will ask them, “Where’s the paint that you used to cover the wall?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: In my fury I’ll cause a storm to break out. In my anger rain will pour down, and hailstones will destroy the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will tear down the wall that the prophets covered up with paint. I will level it and expose its foundation. When the wall falls, they will be destroyed by it. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will unleash my fury on the wall and on those who covered it up with paint.
“ ‘Then I will say to you, “The wall is gone, and so are those who painted it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophets of Israel who prophesied to Jerusalem are gone. Those who said that everything was alright, when it wasn’t alright, are gone, declares the Almighty Lord.” ’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, look at the women among your people who make up prophecies, and prophesy against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: How horrible it will be for women who sew magic charms for people’s wrists and make magic veils of every size for people’s heads. You want to trap people. You want to control the lives of my people for your own profit.
speaker: Narrator

text: You dishonor me in front of my people for a few handfuls of barley and a few pieces of bread. You kill people who shouldn’t die, and you spare the lives of people who shouldn’t live. You lie to my people who are willing to listen.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I’m against the magic charms that you use to trap people like birds. I will tear them from your arms and free the people that you have trapped.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will tear off your magic veils and rescue my people from your power so that they will no longer be under your control. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have discouraged righteous people with your lies, even though I hadn’t brought them any grief. You encouraged wicked people not to turn from their wicked ways to save their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why you will no longer see false visions or make predictions. I will rescue my people from your power. Then you will know that I am the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of Israel’s leaders came to me and sat down in front of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, these people are devoted to their idols, and they are allowing themselves to fall into sin. Should they be allowed to ask me for help?
speaker: Narrator

text: “So speak to them. Tell them, ‘This is what the Lord says: Suppose an Israelite is devoted to idols and allows himself to fall into sin. Suppose he goes to a prophet to ask for my help. I, the Lord, will give that Israelite an answer, the answer that his many idols deserve.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will do this to recapture the hearts of the nation of Israel. They have deserted me because of their disgusting idols.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So tell the nation of Israel, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Change the way you think and act! Turn away from your idols, and don’t return to any of your disgusting things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose an Israelite or a foreigner who lives in Israel deserts me by devoting himself to idols and by allowing himself to fall into sin. If he goes to a prophet to ask for my help, I, the Lord, will give him an answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will reject him, and I will make an example of him. I will exclude him from my people. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘If a prophet is tricked into giving a prophecy, it is I, the Lord, who tricked the prophet. I will use my power against you and destroy you from among my people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both of you will suffer for your sins. The prophet will be as guilty as you are when you ask for his help.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people of Israel will no longer wander away from me. They will no longer dishonor me with all their sins. Then they will be my people, and I will be their God, declares the Almighty Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, suppose a country sins against me by being unfaithful to me. I will use my power against it, cut off its food supply, send a famine to it, and destroy its people and animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if these three men—Noah, Daniel, and Job—were in that country, they would, by their righteousness, rescue only themselves,” declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose I send wild animals through that country and they make it childless and turn it into such a wasteland that no one travels through it because of the animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I live, declares the Almighty Lord, not even Noah, Daniel, and Job could rescue their own sons or daughters. They could rescue only themselves. And the country would become a wasteland.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose I bring a war against that country by saying, ‘I will let a war go throughout this country.’ Suppose I destroy the people and the animals in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I live, declares the Almighty Lord, not even Noah, Daniel, and Job could rescue their sons or daughters. They could rescue only themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose I send a plague into that country or pour out my fury on it by killing people and destroying animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I live, declares the Almighty Lord, not even Noah, Daniel, and Job could, by their righteousness, rescue their sons or daughters. They could rescue only themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Almighty Lord says: I will surely send four terrible punishments against Jerusalem. I will send wars, famines, wild animals, and plagues. They will destroy people and animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: But some people will survive. Some of your sons and daughters will be brought out. When they come out to you, you will see how they live. Then you will be comforted after the disasters that I will bring on Jerusalem, after every disaster that I will bring against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be comforted when you see how they live. Then you will know that everything I have done was done for a reason,” declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, what good is the wood from a vine? Is it better than the wood from a tree in the forest?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do people use it to make something? Do they make a peg from it to hang things on?
speaker: Narrator

text: No! It is only thrown into the fire as fuel. The fire burns up both its ends and chars its middle. Then can it be used to make anything?
speaker: Narrator

text: When the vine was in perfect condition, it couldn’t be made into anything. How can it be used to make anything after the fire has burned and charred it?
speaker: Narrator

text: “So this is what the Almighty Lord says: As a vine is taken from among the trees in the forest to be used to feed the fire, so I will take the people who live in Jerusalem to punish them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn against the people of Jerusalem. Even though they have escaped one fire, another fire will burn them. Then they will know that I am the Lord, because I will turn against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn the country into a wasteland because they have been unfaithful,” declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, make known to the people of Jerusalem the disgusting things they have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says to the people of Jerusalem: Your birthplace and your ancestors were in the land of the Canaanites. Your father was an Amorite, and your mother was a Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you were born, your umbilical cord wasn’t cut. You weren’t washed with water to make you clean. You weren’t rubbed with salt or wrapped in cloth.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one who saw you felt sorry enough for you to do any of these things. But you were thrown into an open field. You were rejected when you were born.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Then I went by you and saw you kicking around in your own blood. I said to you, “Live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I made you grow like a plant in the field. You grew up, matured, and became a young woman. Your breasts developed, and your hair grew. Yet, you were naked and bare.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘I went by you again and looked at you. You were old enough to make love to. So I spread my robe over you, and covered your naked body. I promised to love you, and I exchanged marriage vows with you. You became mine, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Then I bathed you with water, and I washed off your blood. I poured olive oil over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I put an embroidered dress on you and fine leather sandals on your feet. I dressed you in fine linen and covered you with silk.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave you jewelry. I put bracelets on your wrists and a necklace around your neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: I put a ring in your nose, earrings on your ears, and a beautiful crown on your head.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you wore gold and silver jewelry. You were dressed in fine linen, silk, and embroidered clothes. Your food was flour, honey, and olive oil. You were very beautiful, and eventually you became a queen.
speaker: Narrator

text: You became famous in every nation because of your beauty. Your beauty was perfect because I gave you my glory, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘But you trusted your beauty, and you used your fame to become a prostitute. You had sex with everyone who walked by.
speaker: Narrator

text: You took some of your clothes and made your worship sites colorful. This is where you acted like a prostitute. Such things shouldn’t happen. They shouldn’t occur.
speaker: Narrator

text: You took your beautiful gold and silver jewelry that I had given you and made male idols for yourself. Then you committed adultery with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You took off your embroidered clothes and covered the idols with them. You offered my olive oil and incense in their presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: You also offered them sweet and fragrant sacrifices. You gave flour, olive oil, and honey—all the food that I gave you to eat. This is what happened, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘You took your sons and daughters, who belonged to me, and you sacrificed them as food to idols. Wasn’t your prostitution enough?
speaker: Narrator

text: You slaughtered my children and presented them as burnt offerings to idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: With all the disgusting things that you did and all your acts of prostitution, you didn’t remember the time when you were young. You didn’t remember when you were naked and bare, kicking around in your own blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘How horrible! How horrible it will be for you! declares the Almighty Lord. After all your wickedness,
speaker: Narrator

text: you built yourself platforms and illegal worship sites in every city square.
speaker: Narrator

text: You also built worship sites at the head of every street. You used your beauty to seduce people there. You offered your body to everyone who passed by. You increased your acts of prostitution.
speaker: Narrator

text: You had sex with your lustful neighbors, the Egyptians. You used your prostitution to make me angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘So I used my power against you. I took away some of your land, and I handed you over to your greedy enemies, the Philistines, who were ashamed of what you had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘You had sex with the Assyrians because you weren’t satisfied. You still weren’t satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you increased your acts of prostitution to include the land of the merchants, the Babylonians. Even after that, you weren’t satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘You have no will power! declares the Almighty Lord. You do everything a shameless prostitute does.
speaker: Narrator

text: You build your platforms at the head of every street and place your illegal worship sites in every square. Yet, you aren’t like other prostitutes, because you don’t want to be paid.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are an adulterous wife who prefers strangers to her husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: All prostitutes get paid. But you give gifts to all your lovers and bribe them to come to you from all directions to have sex with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are a different kind of prostitute. No one goes after you for favors. You are the opposite. You pay them, and you don’t accept payment.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Listen to the Lord’s word, you prostitute.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Almighty Lord says: You exposed yourself and uncovered your naked body when you gave yourself to your lovers and to all your disgusting idols. You also killed your children and sacrificed their blood to these idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why I will gather all your lovers with whom you found pleasure. I will have all those who love you and hate you gather around. I will uncover your body for them, and they will see you naked.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will punish you the same way that those who are guilty of prostitution and murder are punished. I will give you the death penalty in my fury and burning anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will hand you over to your lovers. They will destroy your platforms and tear down your illegal worship sites. They will tear off your clothes, take away your beautiful jewelry, and leave you naked and bare.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will also bring a mob against you. They will stone you and cut you into pieces with their swords.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will burn your houses and punish you in the presence of many women. I will put an end to your prostitution, and you will no longer pay others.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will rest from my fury against you, and I will stop being angry. I will be at peace. I will no longer be angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘You didn’t remember the time when you were young, and you made me very angry with all these things. So I will pay you back for what you have done, declares the Almighty Lord. Didn’t you make wicked plans in addition to all your disgusting practices?
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Everyone who uses proverbs will speak the following saying against you: Like mother, like daughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are your mother’s daughter. She rejected her husband and her children. You are exactly like your sisters. They rejected their husbands and their children. Your mother was a Hittite, and your father was an Amorite.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Your older sister was Samaria. She and her daughters lived north of you. Your younger sister is Sodom. She lives south of you with her daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: You didn’t follow their ways. You didn’t do the same disgusting things that they did. It only took you a little time to be more corrupt than they ever were.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I live, declares the Almighty Lord, your sister Sodom and her daughters never did what you and your daughters have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what your sister Sodom has done wrong. She and her daughters were proud that they had plenty of food and had peace and security. They didn’t help the poor and the needy.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were arrogant and did disgusting things in front of me. So I did away with them when I saw this.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Samaria didn’t commit half the sins you did. You have done many more disgusting things than they ever did. Because of all the disgusting things that you have done, you make your sisters look innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will have to suffer disgrace because you accused your sisters. Yet, your sins are more disgusting than theirs. They look like they are innocent compared to you. Be ashamed of yourself and suffer disgrace, because you have made your sisters look like they are innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘I will restore the fortunes of Sodom and her daughters, and Samaria and her daughters. I will also restore your fortune along with theirs.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will have to suffer disgrace and be ashamed of everything you have done, including comforting them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Sodom and her daughters and Samaria and her daughters return to what they once were, you and your daughters will return to what you once were.
speaker: Narrator

text: You didn’t mention your sister Sodom when you were arrogant.
speaker: Narrator

text: You didn’t mention her before your wickedness was revealed. Now the daughters of Aram  and their neighbors despise you. The daughters of the Philistines also despise you. Those around you hate you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must suffer because of all the crude and disgusting things you have done, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I will give you what you deserve. You despised your marriage vows and rejected my promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will remember the promise that I made with you when you were young, and I will make it a promise that will last forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will remember what you have done. You will be ashamed when I return your older and younger sisters to you. I will give them to you as daughters, but not because of my promise with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will make my promise with you, and you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will remember and be ashamed. You will never again open your mouth because of your disgrace when I forgive you for everything you did, declares the Almighty Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, tell this riddle. Give this illustration to the nation of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: A large eagle came to Lebanon. It had large wings with long, colorful feathers. It took hold of the top of a cedar tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: It broke off the highest twig and carried it to a country of merchants. It planted the twig in a city of merchants.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Then it took a seedling from that country and planted the seedling in fertile soil. The eagle planted the seedling like a willow where there was plenty of water.
speaker: Narrator

text: The plant sprouted and grew into a low vine that spread over the ground. Its branches turned upward toward the eagle, but its roots grew downward. So it became a vine, producing branches and growing shoots.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘There was another large eagle with large wings and many feathers. Now, the vine stretched its roots toward this eagle and sent its branches toward the eagle so that the eagle could water it. The vine turned away from the garden where it was planted.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was planted in good soil beside plenty of water so that it could grow branches, bear fruit, and become a wonderful vine.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the nation of Israel, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Will this vine live and grow? Won’t the first eagle uproot it and tear off its fruit? Then it will wither. All the leaves on its branches will wither. It won’t take much strength or many people to pull the vine up by its roots.
speaker: Narrator

text: It might be planted again, but will it live and grow? It will wither completely when the east wind blows on it. It will certainly wither in the garden where it is growing.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Ask these rebellious people, ‘Don’t you know what this means?’ Tell them, ‘The king of Babylon came to Jerusalem and captured its king and its leaders. He brought them home with him to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took someone from the royal family, made a treaty with him, and made him promise to be loyal. He took away the leading citizens from Judah
speaker: Narrator

text: so that it would remain a humiliated country and be unable to regain its power. The country could only survive by keeping the treaty.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king of Judah rebelled against the king of Babylon by sending his messengers to Egypt to get horses and many soldiers. Will the king of Judah succeed? Will anyone who does such things escape? He can’t break a treaty and go unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘As I live, declares the Almighty Lord, the king of Judah will die in Babylonia. He will die in the country of the king who appointed him king of Judah. The king of Judah broke his promise and his treaty with the king of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even with a large army and many people, Pharaoh will not be able to help him in battle when the Babylonians put up dirt ramps and set up blockades to kill many people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Judah broke the promise and the treaty that he pledged to keep. He did all these things, and he can’t go unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘So this is what the Almighty Lord says: As I live, I will certainly punish you for rejecting my promise and hating my treaty.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will spread my net over you to catch you in my trap. I will take you to Babylon and judge you there for rebelling against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The best of your troops will die in battle. Anyone who remains will be scattered in every direction that the wind blows. Then you will know that I, the Lord, have spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I, too, will take hold of the top of a cedar tree. I will break off the highest twig and plant it on a high and lofty mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will plant it on a high mountain in Israel. It will grow branches and produce fruit. It will become a magnificent cedar tree. Every kind of bird will nest in it and find a home in the shelter of its branches.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the trees in the field will know that I am the Lord. I cut down tall trees, and I make small trees grow tall. I dry up green trees, and I make dry trees grow. I, the Lord, have spoken, and I will do it.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “What do you mean when you use this proverb about the land of Israel: ‘Fathers have eaten sour grapes, and their children’s teeth are set on edge’?
speaker: Narrator

text: As I live, declares the Almighty Lord, you will no longer use this proverb in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The life of every person belongs to me. Fathers and their children belong to me. The person who sins will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose a righteous person does what is fair and right.
speaker: Narrator

text: He doesn’t eat at the illegal mountain worship sites or look for help from the idols of the nation of Israel. He doesn’t dishonor his neighbor’s wife or have sexual intercourse with a woman while she is having her period.
speaker: Narrator

text: He doesn’t oppress anyone. He returns what a borrower gives him as security for a loan. He doesn’t rob anyone. He gives food to people who are hungry, and he gives clothes to those who are naked.
speaker: Narrator

text: He doesn’t lend money for interest or make an excessive profit. He refuses to do evil things, and he judges everyone fairly.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lives by my rules and obeys my laws faithfully. This person is righteous. He will certainly live,” declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But suppose this person has a son who robs and murders. The son does all the things
speaker: Narrator

text: that his father never did. He eats at the illegal mountain worship sites. He dishonors his neighbor’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: He oppresses the poor and needy. He robs. He doesn’t return the security for a loan. He looks to idols for help. He does disgusting things.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lends money for interest and makes excessive profits. Will this person live? He will not live. He has done all these disgusting things. So he must die, and he will be responsible for his own death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But suppose this person has a son. The son sees all the sins that his father does. He is afraid, so he doesn’t do such things.
speaker: Narrator

text: He doesn’t eat at the illegal mountain worship sites or look for help from the idols of the nation of Israel. He doesn’t dishonor his neighbor’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: He doesn’t oppress anyone. He doesn’t keep the security for a loan. He doesn’t rob anyone. He gives food to people who are hungry, and he gives clothes to those who are naked.
speaker: Narrator

text: He refuses to hurt the poor. He doesn’t charge interest or make excessive profits. He obeys my rules and lives by my laws. He won’t die for his father’s sins. He will certainly live.
speaker: Narrator

text: But his father has oppressed others, robbed his relative, and done what is wrong among his people. So the father will die because of his sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you ask, ‘Why isn’t the son punished for his father’s sin?’ It is because the son has done what is fair and right. He obeyed my rules and followed them. He will certainly live.
speaker: Narrator

text: The person who sins will die. A son will not be punished for his father’s sins, and a father will not be punished for his son’s sins. The righteousness of the righteous person will be his own, and the wickedness of the wicked person will be his own.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But suppose a wicked person turns away from all the sins that he has done. He obeys all my laws and does what is fair and right. He will certainly live. He will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the rebellious things that he did will not be remembered. He will live because of the right things that he did.
speaker: Narrator

text: I don’t want wicked people to die.” declares the Almighty Lord. “I want them to turn from their evil ways and live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But suppose a righteous person turns away from doing right and he does evil things. He does all the disgusting things that the wicked person did. Will he live? All the right things that he has done will not be remembered because of his unfaithfulness and because of his sin. He will die because of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you say, ‘The Lord’s way is unfair.’ Listen, nation of Israel, isn’t my way fair? Isn’t it your ways that are unfair?
speaker: Narrator

text: When a righteous person turns away from doing right and does evil things, he will die. He will die because of the evil things he has done.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a wicked person turns away from the wicked things that he has done and does what is fair and right, he will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: He realized what he was doing and turned away from all the rebellious things that he had done. He will certainly live. He will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the nation of Israel says, ‘The Lord’s way is unfair.’ Isn’t my way fair, nation of Israel? Isn’t it your ways that are unfair?
speaker: Narrator

text: “That is why I will judge each of you by what you have done, people of Israel,” declares the Almighty Lord. “Change the way you think and act. Turn away from all the rebellious things that you have done so that you will not fall into sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stop all the rebellious things that you are doing. Get yourselves new hearts and new spirits. Why do you want to die, nation of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: I don’t want anyone to die,” declares the Almighty Lord. “Change the way you think and act!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Sing a funeral song for the princes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say:
Your mother was like a lioness.
She lay down among the lions.
She fed many cubs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One of the cubs she raised became a young lion.
He learned to tear apart the animals he hunted.
He ate people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The nations heard about him,
caught him in their pit,
and brought him with hooks to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lioness waited until she saw that there was no more hope.
Then she took another one of her cubs
and raised him into a young lion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He became a young lion, and he prowled among the lions.
He learned to tear apart the animals he hunted.
He ate people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He destroyed fortresses
and turned cities into wastelands.
The land and everyone living in it
were terrified by the sound of his roar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The nations from every region came together against him.
They spread their net over him
and caught him in their pit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With hooks they put him in a cage
and brought him to the king of Babylon.
They put him in prison
so that his roar wouldn’t be heard anymore
on the mountains of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your mother was like a grapevine
that was planted near water.
It had a lot of fruit and many branches
because there was plenty of water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its branches were strong.
They were used to make scepters for kings.
It grew to be tall with many branches around it,
and everyone saw it because of its many branches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But in anger it was uprooted and thrown to the ground.
The east wind dried up its fruit.
Its strong branches broke off.
They withered and were burned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now it is planted in the desert,
in a dry and waterless land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fire has spread from the vine’s main branch.
Fire has destroyed its fruit.
It no longer has any strong branches
that could be used as a king’s scepter.
This is a funeral song. It is to be used as a funeral song.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the tenth day of the fifth month in the seventh year, some of the leaders of Israel came to ask for the Lord’s help. They sat in front of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, speak to the leaders of Israel. Tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Are you coming to ask me for help? As I live, declares the Almighty Lord, you will not be allowed to ask me for help.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Will you judge them? Will you judge them, son of man? Tell them about the disgusting things their ancestors did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: When I chose Israel, I raised my hand and swore an oath to the descendants of Jacob’s family. I made myself known to them in Egypt. I made a promise to them and said, “I am the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time I promised to bring them out of Egypt to a land that I had chosen for them. This land is the most beautiful land, a land flowing with milk and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to them, “Get rid of the detestable idols that you look to for help. Don’t dishonor yourselves with the disgusting idols of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘But they rebelled against me and refused to listen to me. Not one of them got rid of the detestable idols that they looked to for help. They didn’t abandon the disgusting idols of Egypt. So I was going to pour out my fury on them and unleash my anger on them in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I acted so that my name would not be dishonored among the nations where they were living. While other nations were watching, I made myself known to them by bringing the Israelites out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘So I brought the Israelites out of Egypt and led them into the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave them my laws and made my rules known to them. If people obey them they will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also gave them certain days to worship me as a sign between us so that they would know that I, the Lord, made them holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘But the people of Israel rebelled against me in the desert. They didn’t live by my laws, and they rejected my rules. If people obey them, they will live. They dishonored the days of rest—holy days on which to worship me. So I was going to pour out my fury on them in the desert and completely wipe them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I acted so that my name would not be dishonored among the nations who had watched me bring the Israelites out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also swore an oath to them in the desert. I swore that I would not bring them into the land that I had promised to give them. This land is the most beautiful land, a land flowing with milk and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: They rejected my rules, and they didn’t live by my laws. They dishonored the days to worship me, because their hearts chased disgusting idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I had compassion on them. I didn’t destroy them or completely wipe them out in the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to their children in the desert, “Don’t live by the laws of your ancestors. Don’t obey their rules or dishonor yourselves with their disgusting idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord your God. Live by my laws. Obey my rules and follow them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Set apart certain holy days to worship me. This will be a sign between me and you so that you will know that I am the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘But they rebelled against me. They didn’t live by my laws, and they didn’t obey my rules and follow them. If people obey them, they will live. They dishonored the days to worship me. So I was going to pour out my fury on them and unleash my anger on them in the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I didn’t use my power so that my name would not be dishonored among the nations who had watched me bring the Israelites out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I raised my hand and swore an oath to them in the desert. I promised to scatter them among the nations and force them into other countries.
speaker: Narrator

text: They didn’t follow my rules, and they rejected my laws. They dishonored the days to worship me, and they looked to their ancestors’ disgusting idols for help.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also allowed them to follow laws that were no good and rules by which they could not live.
speaker: Narrator

text: I let them dishonor themselves when they sacrificed all their firstborn sons as gifts to their false gods. I terrified them so that they would know that I am the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the nation of Israel, son of man. Tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Your ancestors insulted me again because they were unfaithful to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I brought them to the land that I promised to give them. When they saw any high hill or any leafy tree, they made sacrifices and brought offerings there to make me angry. There they offered their sacrifices and poured out their wine offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I asked them, “What is this worship site you’re going to?” ’ (So it is still called ‘worship site’ today.)
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the nation of Israel, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Will you dishonor yourselves the way your ancestors did? Will you chase their detestable idols like a prostitute?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You offer your children as sacrifices by burning them alive. You dishonor yourselves with all your disgusting idols to this day. Should you be allowed to ask me for help, nation of Israel?
“ ‘As I live, declares the Almighty Lord, you won’t be allowed to ask me for help.
speaker: Narrator

text: What you have in mind will never happen. You think that you want to be like other nations, like the different people in other countries. You want to serve wood and stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘As I live, declares the Almighty Lord, I will rule you with a mighty hand and a powerful arm, and I will pour out my fury.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring you out from the nations and gather you from the countries where I have scattered you with my mighty hand and powerful arm. I will pour out my fury.
speaker: Narrator
