text: I will bring you into the desert of the nations. There I will put you on trial face to face.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will put you on trial as I put your ancestors on trial in the desert of Egypt, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will make you suffer punishment and make you keep the terms of the promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will get rid of rebels and those who do wrong against me. I will bring you out of the land where you are living. You will never enter Israel. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Nation of Israel, this is what the Almighty Lord says: Serve your disgusting idols. But afterwards, you will listen to me. You will no longer dishonor my holy name with your gifts and your disgusting idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘The entire nation of Israel, everyone in the land, will worship me on my holy mountain, the high mountain of Israel, declares the Almighty Lord. There I will accept you. There I will look for your offerings, your best gifts, and all your holy gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I bring you out from the nations and gather you from the countries where you have been scattered, I will accept you as if you were a pleasing sacrifice. Through you I will reveal myself as holy to the nations that are watching.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know that I am the Lord, because I will bring you to the land of Israel, the land that I promised to give your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: There you will remember the way you lived and everything you did to dishonor yourselves. You will be disgusted by every wrong thing that you did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know that I am the Lord, because I will deal with you for the sake of my name. I will not deal with you based on the evil and corrupt things that you have done, nation of Israel, declares the Almighty Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, turn to the south, preach against the south, and prophesy against the forest in the Negev.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell the forest in the Negev, ‘Listen to the Lord’s word. This is what the Almighty Lord says: I am about to set fire to you to destroy all your green trees and all your dry trees. The blazing fire will not be put out. It will burn the whole land from the south to the north.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then everyone will know that I, the Lord, started the fire. It will never be put out.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said, “Oh no! Almighty Lord, no! The people already say that I’m only telling stories.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, turn to Jerusalem, preach against the holy places. Prophesy against the land of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell the land of Israel, ‘This is what the Lord says: I am against you. I will take my sword out of its scabbard and kill the righteous people and the wicked people among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m going to kill the righteous people and the wicked people among you. That is why my sword will come out of its scabbard to be used against everyone from the south to the north.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then everyone will know that I, the Lord, have taken my sword from its scabbard, and I will not put it back again.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So, son of man, groan with a breaking heart and with bitter crying while the people watch you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they ask you why you are groaning, say, ‘News has come that will discourage everyone. People’s hands will hang limp, their hearts will lose courage, and their knees will become as weak as water. It’s coming! It will surely take place!’ declares the Almighty Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Son of man, prophesy. Tell them, ‘This is what the Lord says:
A sword, a sword is sharpened and polished,
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s sharpened to kill
and polished to flash like lightning.
How can we rejoice?
My son has refused to be disciplined or punished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sword has been handed over to be polished,
to be placed in the hand.
The sword is being sharpened and polished
to be placed in the hands of killers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘Cry and mourn, son of man,
because the sword will be used against my people
and against all the princes of Israel.
I will throw the princes and my people on the sword.
So beat your breast, and grieve.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Testing will surely come.
What if you refuse to be disciplined again?
Won’t you be tested? declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So prophesy, son of man.
Clap your hands!
Let the sword strike again and again.
It’s the sword for killing.
It’s the sword for killing many people.
It’s the sword that surrounds them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have appointed my sword to slaughter people at all their gates
so that their hearts will sink and many will die.
Yes! It’s ready to flash like lightning.
It’s polished to kill.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sword, cut to the right.
Cut to the left
or wherever your blade is turned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will also clap my hands and rest from my fury.
I, the Lord, have spoken.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, mark two roads that the king of Babylon and his sword can take. Both of these roads should start from the same country. Make a sign, and put it where the roads start to fork toward the cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mark the road that the king and his sword can take to the Ammonite city of Rabbah, and mark the road that leads to Judah and the fortified city of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Babylon will stop where the roads branch off, where there is a fork in the road. Then he will look for omens. He will shake some arrows, ask his household gods for help, and examine animal livers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The omens will indicate that he should go to the right, to Jerusalem. So he will set up his battering rams there, give the order to kill, raise a battle cry, aim the battering rams against the city gates, put up ramps, and set up blockades.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people won’t believe this because they have made treaties with other nations. But the king of Babylon will remind them of their sins, and they will be captured.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Almighty Lord says: You make people remember how sinful you are because you openly do wrong. You show your sins in everything you do. So you will be taken captive.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You dishonest and wicked prince of Israel, the time for your final punishment has come.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Almighty Lord says: Take off your turban, and get rid of your crown. Things are going to change. Those who are unimportant will become important, and those who are important will become unimportant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ruins! Ruins! I will turn this place into ruins! It will not be restored until its rightful owner comes. Then I will give it to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Son of man, prophesy. Tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says about the Ammonites and their insults:
A sword, a sword is drawn ready to kill.
It’s polished to destroy and flash like lightning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People see false visions about you
and prophesy lies about you.
The sword will be placed on the necks of dishonest, wicked people,
for whom the time of final punishment has come.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘Return your sword to its scabbard.
In the place where you were created,
in the land where you were born,
there I will judge you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will pour out my fury on you
and breathe on you with my fiery anger. 
I will hand you over to cruel people who are skilled in destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will be fuel for the fire.
You will die in the land.
You will no longer be remembered.
I, the Lord, have spoken.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Will you judge, son of man? Will you judge the city of murderers? Then tell it about all the disgusting things that it has done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell it, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Jerusalem, you are the city that murders people who live in you. Your time has come. You dishonor yourself with disgusting idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are guilty because of the people you have killed. You are dishonored because of the disgusting idols you have made. You have brought an end to your days, and you have come to the end of your years. That is why I will make you a disgrace to the nations and a joke in every land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those near and those far away will mock you. Your name will be dishonored, and you will be filled with confusion.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘See how all the princes of Israel who live in you have used their power to murder people.
speaker: Narrator

text: People in you hate their fathers and mothers. They oppress foreigners in you. They oppress orphans and widows in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have despised my holy things and dishonored the day to worship me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of your people slander. They want to kill people. People who live in you eat food sacrificed to idols at the worship sites on the hills, and they sin sexually.
speaker: Narrator

text: Men have sex with their father’s wives. They have sex with women when the women are having their periods and are unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Men do disgusting things with their neighbors’ wives. Some men sexually dishonor their daughters-in-law. Other men who live in you have sex with their sisters, their father’s daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Other people take bribes to murder people. You collect interest and make excessive profits. You make profits by mistreating your neighbors. You have forgotten me, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘I will use my power against you because of the excessive profits you have made and the murders you have committed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Will you still be brave? Will you remain strong when I deal with you? I, the Lord, have spoken, and I will do it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will scatter you among the nations and force you into other countries. I will put an end to your uncleanness.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be dishonored in the sight of the nations. Then you will know that I am the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, the people of Israel have become worthless to me. All of them are like copper, tin, iron, and lead in a smelting furnace. They are like the impurities left from silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Almighty Lord says: All of you have become worthless. That is why I’m going to gather you in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: People gather silver, copper, iron, lead, and tin together in a smelting furnace to melt them with a fiery blast. In the same way, in my anger and fury I will gather you and put you in the city. I will melt you there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, I will gather you, breathe on you with my fiery anger, and melt you in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be melted in the city like silver that is melted in a furnace. Then you will know that I, the Lord, have poured out my fury on you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, tell the city, ‘You are an unclean land that has not had rain during the day of my anger. You have not been made clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your princes are like roaring lions who tear their prey into pieces. They eat people and take their treasures and precious belongings. They turn many women into widows.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your priests violate my teachings and dishonor my holy things. They don’t distinguish between what is holy and what is unholy. They don’t teach the difference between what is clean and what is unclean. They ignore the days to worship me. So I am dishonored among the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your leaders are like wolves that tear their prey into pieces. They murder and destroy people to make excessive profits.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your prophets cover up these things by seeing false visions and by prophesying lies. They say, “This is what the Almighty Lord says.” Yet, the Lord hasn’t spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: The common people oppress and rob others. They do wrong to humble people and to poor people. They oppress foreigners for no reason.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘I looked for someone among you who could build walls or stand in front of me by the gaps in the walls to defend the land and keep it from being destroyed. But I couldn’t find anyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I will pour out my anger on you, and with my fiery anger I will consume you. This is because of all the things you have done,’ declares the Almighty Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, there were once two women, daughters of the same mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: They became prostitutes in Egypt when they were young. There men fondled and caressed their breasts.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The older girl was named Oholah, and the younger girl was named Oholibah. I married them, and they gave birth to sons and daughters. Oholah represents Samaria, and Oholibah represents Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Oholah acted like a prostitute, although she was my wife. She lusted after her Assyrian lovers who lived nearby.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were governors and commanders clothed in purple. They were all handsome young men who rode on horses.
speaker: Narrator

text: She became a prostitute for all the important men in Assyria. She dishonored herself with the idols of all those with whom she fell in love.
speaker: Narrator

text: She continued the prostitution that she started in Egypt. When she was young, men went to bed with her, caressed her breasts, and treated her like a prostitute.
speaker: Narrator

text: “That is why I handed her over to her lovers, to the Assyrians whom she lusted after.
speaker: Narrator

text: They stripped her naked, took away her sons and daughters, and killed her with a sword. Women gossiped about how she was punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Even though her younger sister Oholibah saw this, Oholibah lusted after men more than her sister did. Oholibah’s prostitution became worse than her sister’s prostitution.
speaker: Narrator

text: She lusted after the Assyrians who were nearby. They were governors and commanders in full dress. They were mounted horsemen, all of them desirable young men.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw that she was dishonoring herself. Both sisters acted the same way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet, she carried her prostitution even further. She saw pictures of men carved on walls. They were figures of Babylonian men, painted in bright red.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men had belts around their waists and flowing turbans on their heads. All of them looked like Babylonian officers who were born in Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: She fell in love with them at first sight and sent messengers to them in Babylonia.
speaker: Narrator

text: So these men came from Babylon, went to bed with her, and dishonored her with their lust. After they had dishonored her, she turned away from them in disgust.
speaker: Narrator

text: “She carried out her prostitution openly, and she lay around naked. I turned away from her in disgust as I had turned away from her sister.
speaker: Narrator

text: She remembered how she had been a prostitute in Egypt when she was young. So she took part in even more prostitution.
speaker: Narrator

text: She lusted after her lovers, whose genitals were like those of donkeys and whose semen was like that of horses.
speaker: Narrator

text: So she longed to do the sinful things she did when she was young in Egypt, when young men caressed and fondled her breasts.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Oholibah, this is what the Almighty Lord says: I’m going to stir up your lovers against you. They are the lovers you turned away from in disgust. I will bring them against you from every side.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring men from Babylon and from all Babylonia, men from Pekod, Shoa, and Koa, as well as all the Assyrians. They are desirable young men, governors and commanders, military officers and important men. All of them ride on horses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will attack you from the north, with chariots and wagons and with a large number of troops. They will attack you from all around with small and large shields and with helmets. I have handed you over to them for punishment. They will punish you with their own kind of punishment.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will direct my burning anger against you so that they will deal with you in anger. They will cut off your nose and ears and kill everyone who remains. They will take your sons and your daughters and burn down whatever is left.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will rip off your clothes and take away your beautiful jewels.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will put a stop to your sinning and to your prostitution, which you began in Egypt. You won’t desire these things anymore or remember Egypt anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Almighty Lord says: I’m going to hand you over to those you hate and to those you turned away from in disgust.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will treat you hatefully and take away everything that you have worked for. They will leave you naked and bare. The shame of your prostitution will be revealed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your sinning and your prostitution have done this to you, because you lusted after the nations and dishonored yourself with their idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: You’ve acted the same way as your sister. That is why I will put her cup in your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Almighty Lord says:
You will drink from your sister’s cup,
a cup that is deep and wide.
You will be scorned and mocked,
because this cup holds so much.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The cup of your sister Samaria will be filled
with drunkenness and sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will drink from it and drain it.
You will break it into pieces
and tear your breasts off your body.
I have spoken, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Almighty Lord says: You have forgotten me and turned your back on me. So you will be punished for your sinning and prostitution.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to me, “Son of man, will you judge Oholah and Oholibah and tell them about their disgusting practices?
speaker: Narrator

text: They have committed adultery. Their hands are covered with blood. They commit adultery with their idols. They have sacrificed the children they gave birth to for me as burnt offerings to idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have also done this to me: They have polluted my holy places when they do these things and dishonored the days to worship me.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they sacrificed their children to their idols, they came into my holy place and dishonored it. That is what they’ve done in my temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They even sent messengers to invite men to come from far away. When the men arrived, they washed themselves for the men, painted their eyes, and put on their jewels.
speaker: Narrator

text: They sat on their fine couches with tables in front of them. They put my incense and my olive oil on their tables.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I heard the noise from a carefree crowd. A large number of people came from the desert, and they put bracelets on the women’s wrists and beautiful crowns on their heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said, ‘She is worn out from her acts of adultery.’ Yet, men continued to have sex with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Men slept with her. They slept with those sinful women, Oholah and Oholibah just as they slept with a prostitute.
speaker: Narrator

text: Righteous people will punish these women for adultery and for murder, because these women have committed adultery and their hands are covered with blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Almighty Lord says: Bring together a mob against the people of Samaria and Jerusalem. Hand them over to terror and looting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the mob will stone them and kill them with swords. The mob will kill their sons and daughters and burn their homes.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I will put a stop to the sinning in the land, and all the women will be warned not to sin as they do.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will be punished for their sins, and they will pay for their sin of idolatry. Then they will know that I am the Almighty Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the tenth day of the tenth month in the ninth year, the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, write down today’s date. The king of Babylon has surrounded Jerusalem this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell these rebellious people a story. Tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says:
Put the pot on the fire; put it on.
Pour water in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cut the meat into pieces,
all the best pieces, the thigh and shoulder.
Fill the pot with the meatiest bones
speaker: Narrator

text:
selected from the best sheep.
Pile wood under the pot.
Bring the mixture in the pot to a boil.
Cook the bones that are in it well.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says:
How horrible it will be for that city of murderers,
for that tarnished pot.
Its tarnish will not come off.
Empty the meat out of it piece by piece
without choosing any particular piece.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blood is still in that city.
The blood was poured on a bare rock.
It wasn’t poured on the ground where dust would cover it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In order to stir up my fury so that I would pay that city back,
I put the blood of its victims on a bare rock.
Now that blood can’t be covered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says:
How horrible it will be for that city of murderers.
I, too, will pile the wood high.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pile it high, and light the fire.
Cook the meat thoroughly, stir the mixture,
and let the bones burn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then set the empty pot on the coals
so that it gets hot and its copper glows.
Its impurities will melt away,
and its tarnish will burn off.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘I have worn myself out trying to clean this pot. Even the fire can’t take away its thick tarnish.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tried to clean you of your filthy lust, but you wouldn’t clean yourself from your filth. You will never be clean until I unleash my fury on you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, the Lord, have spoken. It will happen, and I will do it. I will not ignore you, pity you, or change my plans. I will punish you because of the way you lived and because of everything you have done,’ ” declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, with one blow I’m going to take away from you the person you love the most. But you must not mourn, cry, or let tears run down your face.
speaker: Narrator

text: Groan silently. Don’t grieve for the person who dies. Tie on your turban, and put on your sandals. Don’t cover your face or eat the food that mourners eat.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I spoke to the people in the morning, and in the evening my wife died. The next morning I did as I was ordered.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people asked me, “Tell us, what do these things that you are doing mean to us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: I told them, “The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Tell the nation of Israel, “This is what the Almighty Lord says: I’m going to dishonor my holy place. You brag that my holy place gives you strength. It’s the thing you love the most. It’s your hearts’ desire. So the sons and daughters that you left behind will die in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you must do as I did. Don’t cover your faces or eat the food that mourners eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leave your turbans on your heads and your sandals on your feet. Don’t grieve or cry! You will waste away because of your guilt and groan to one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ezekiel is a sign to you. You will do everything he has done. Then you will know that I am the Almighty Lord.” ’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, on that day I will take their stronghold away from them. It makes them happy and proud. It is their hearts’ desire and the thing they love the most. I will also take away their sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day a refugee will come to you to tell you the news.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that very day your mouth will be opened, and you will talk to the refugee. You will speak and not be silent anymore. You will be a sign to them. Then they will know that I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, turn to the Ammonites and prophesy against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell the Ammonites, ‘Listen to the Almighty Lord’s word. This is what the Almighty Lord says: You were glad when my holy place was dishonored, when the land of Israel was ruined, and when the nation of Judah went into exile.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why I’m going to hand you over to the people in the east. They will possess your land. They will set up their camps and pitch their tents among you. They will eat your crops and drink your milk.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn Rabbah into a pasture for camels, and I will turn Ammon into a resting place for sheep. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: You clapped your hands and stomped your feet. You rejoiced and felt contempt for the land of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why I will use my power against you and hand you over to the nations as loot. I will wipe you out from among the nations, make you disappear, and destroy you. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Moab and Seir said, “The nation of Judah is like all the other nations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why I’m going to open up the cities that protect Moab’s borders. They are the beautiful cities of Beth Jeshimoth, Baal Meon, and Kiriathaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will hand the Moabites and the Ammonites over to the people in the east. So the Ammonites will no longer be remembered among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will punish Moab. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Edom took revenge on the nation of Judah and became guilty because of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: So this is what the Almighty Lord says: I will use my power against Edom. I will wipe out people and animals. I will turn the land into ruins from Teman to Dedan. People will die in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will use my people Israel to take revenge on Edom. My people will deal with Edom based on my anger and my fury. Then the Edomites will know my revenge, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: The Philistines have taken revenge with spiteful hearts. They have tried to destroy their long-time enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: So this is what the Almighty Lord says: I’m going to use my power against the Philistines, cut off the Cherethites, and destroy the people that are left on the coast.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take fierce revenge on them and punish them with fury. I will take revenge on them. Then they will know that I am the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the month in the eleventh year, the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, Tyre said this about Jerusalem: ‘The city that was the gateway for the nations is destroyed, and its doors are swung open to me. I’ll get rich now that it’s ruined.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So this is what the Almighty Lord says: I am against you, Tyre. I will bring many nations against you as the waves on the sea rise.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will destroy the walls of Tyre and tear down its towers. Then I will sweep up the dust and turn Tyre into a bare rock.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will become a place by the sea where people spread their fishing nets. I have spoken, declares the Almighty Lord. It will become a prize for the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people in the villages and on the mainland will die in battle. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Almighty Lord says: From the north I’m going to bring King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon against you, Tyre. He is the greatest king. He will bring horses, chariots, war horses, many people, and many troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will destroy the villages on your mainland. He will set up blockades, put up dirt ramps, and raise his shields against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will direct his battering rams against your walls, and he will cut down your towers with his axes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will have so many horses that their dust will cover you. The noise from the war horses, wagon wheels, and chariots will shake your walls when he enters your gates. He will enter as people enter a conquered city.
speaker: Narrator

text: With his horses’ hoofs he will trample all your streets. He will kill your people in battle, and your strong pillars will fall to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: His troops will loot your riches and take your goods as prizes. They will destroy your walls and tear down your delightful homes. They will throw your stones, wood, and soil into the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will put a stop to your noisy songs, and the music from your harps will no longer be heard.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn you into bare rock. You will become a place to spread fishing nets. You will never be rebuilt. I, the Lord, have spoken, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Almighty Lord says to Tyre: The people who live on the coast will shake with fear when they hear about your defeat. They will groan when your people are wounded and slaughtered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the princes from the coast will come down from their thrones. They will remove their robes and take off their embroidered clothes. Dressed in terror, they will sit on the ground. They will tremble constantly and be shocked at you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they will sing this funeral song for you:
Tyre, you famous city, you have been destroyed.
You have been shattered by the sea.
You and your people ruled the sea.
All your people terrified those who lived by the coast.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your defeat will make the people who live by the coast tremble.
Your end will terrify the islands in the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Almighty Lord says: I will turn your city into ruins like cities that have no one living in them. I will bring the deep ocean over you, and the Mediterranean Sea will cover you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring you down with those who descend to the grave to join the people of long ago. I will make you live below the earth among the ancient ruins with those who go down to the grave. You will never return or take your place in the land of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn you into a terror, and you will no longer exist. People will look for you, but they will never see you again,” declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, sing a funeral song about Tyre.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tyre is the city at the entrance to the sea. It is the merchant to the nations. Say to Tyre, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says:
Tyre, you used to brag about your perfect beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your home is the sea. 
“ ‘Your builders made your beauty perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your builders made all your boards from pine trees on Mount Hermon.
They took cedar trees from Lebanon to make a mast for you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They made your oars from oaks in Bashan.
They made your deck from pine trees on the shores of Cyprus.
It had ivory set in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your sails were made out of fine embroidered linen from Egypt.
They were like your flags.
Your awnings were violet and purple.
They came from the coasts of Elishah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People from Sidon and Arvad used to row you.
Your own skilled people were your sailors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Master shipbuilders from Gebal went inside you to caulk your seams.
All the ships on the sea and their sailors
docked alongside you to trade with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People from Persia, Lud, and Put were soldiers in your army.
They hung their shields and helmets inside you.
Their victories made you look good.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘People from Arvad and Helech  were guards all around your walls. People from Gammad guarded your towers. They hung their shields all around your walls, making your beauty perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘People from Tarshish traded with you because you were so very rich. They exchanged silver, iron, tin, and lead for your merchandise.
speaker: Narrator

text: People from Greece, Tubal, and Meshech traded with you. They exchanged slaves and bronze items for your goods.
speaker: Narrator

text: People from Beth Togarmah exchanged horses, war horses, and mules for your merchandise.
speaker: Narrator

text: People from Dedan traded goods with you. You traded with many people on the coasts, and they brought you ivory and ebony as payment.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘People from Syria traded with you because you had so many products. They exchanged emeralds, purple cloth, richly woven cloth, linen, coral, and rubies for your merchandise.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah and Israel traded with you. They exchanged wheat from Minnith, baked goods, honey, olive oil, and balsam for your goods.
speaker: Narrator

text: People from Damascus traded with you because you had so many products. They exchanged wine from Helbon and wool from Sahar.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Danites and Greeks from Uzal traded for your merchandise. They exchanged wrought iron, cassia, and sugar cane for your goods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dedan traded saddle blankets with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arabia and all the officials of Kedar traded with you. They traded lambs, rams, and male goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: The merchants from Sheba and Raamah traded with you. They traded the finest spices, precious stones, and gold for your merchandise.
speaker: Narrator

text: Haran, Canneh, Eden, the merchants from Sheba, Assyria, and Kilmad traded with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: In your marketplace they traded for beautiful clothes, purple robes, embroidered cloth, and many multicolored rugs with woven and twisted cords.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘Ships from Tarshish carried your goods.
You were like a ship filled with heavy cargo in the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your rowers took you out to the high seas,
and an east wind wrecked you in the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your wealth, your merchandise, and the goods you sell,
your mariners and your sailors,
your caulkers and your merchants,
your soldiers and everyone else on board
sank into the sea when your ship was wrecked.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘When your sailors cried out, people on the shore trembled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the rowers, the sailors,
and all the mariners came down from their ships
and stood on the shore.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They cried loudly and bitterly over you.
They put dust on their heads and covered themselves with ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They shaved their heads because of you and put on sackcloth.
They cried over you with bitterness and with bitter mourning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sang a funeral song for you with loud crying:
“Who is like Tyre, the city destroyed in the sea?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your merchandise was sent overseas.
You filled many people with your great wealth and your goods.
You made the kings of the earth rich.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now you are wrecked in the sea, at the bottom of the sea.
Your goods and your whole crew sank with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All those who live on the coasts are horrified because of you.
Their kings are terribly afraid.
Their faces show their fear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The merchants among the nations laugh at you.
You have come to a terrible end,
and you will never exist again.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Son of man, tell the ruler of Tyre, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says:
In your arrogance you say,
“I’m a god. I sit on God’s throne in the sea.”
But you’re only human and not a god,
although you think you are a god.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You think that you are wiser than Daniel
and that no secret can be hidden from you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because you are wise and understanding,
you’ve made yourself rich.
You saved gold and silver in your treasuries.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because of your great skill in trading,
you’ve made yourself very wealthy.
You have become arrogant because of your wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says:
You think you are wise like God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why I am going to bring foreigners against you,
the most ruthless foreigners among the nations.
They will draw their swords against your fine wisdom
and dishonor your greatness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will throw you into a pit,
and you will die a violent death in the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will no longer say that you are a god
when you face those who kill you.
You will be a human, not a god, in the hands of those who kill you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will die at the hands of foreigners like a godless person.
I have spoken,’ ” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Son of man, sing a funeral song for the ruler of Tyre. Tell him, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says:
You were the perfect example,
full of wisdom and perfect in beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You were in Eden, God’s garden.
You were covered with every kind of precious stone:
red quartz, topaz, crystal,
beryl, onyx, gray quartz, sapphire,
turquoise, and emerald.
Your settings and your sockets
were made of gold when you were created.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I appointed an angel  to guard you.
You were on God’s holy mountain.
You walked among fiery stones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your behavior was perfect from the time you were created,
until evil was found in you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You traded far and wide. You learned to be violent, and you sinned.
So I threw you down from God’s mountain in disgrace.
The guardian angel forced you out from the fiery stones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You became too proud because of your beauty.
You wasted your wisdom because of your greatness.
So I threw you to the ground
and left you in front of the kings
so that they could see you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You dishonored your own holy places
because of your many sins and dishonest trade.
So I set fire to you to burn you up.
I turned you into ashes on the ground
in the presence of all who saw you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the nations who knew you are horrified because of you.
You have come to a terrible end,
and you will never exist again.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, turn to Sidon and prophesy against it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell it, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says:
I’m against you, Sidon.
I will show my greatness through you.
Then people will know that I am the Lord,
because I will punish you and show you how holy I am.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will send a plague against you
and make blood flow in your streets.
Your people will fall dead.
People with swords will attack you from every side.
Then they will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The nation of Israel will no longer be hurt
by prickly thorns or sharp briars from everyone around them.
Then they will know that I am the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: When I gather the people of Israel from the nations where they were scattered, I will show that I am holy as the nations watch. The people of Israel will live in their own land, the land I gave to my servant Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will live there in safety. They will build homes and plant vineyards. They will live in safety when I punish all the surrounding people who treat them with scorn. Then they will know that I am the Lord their God.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the twelfth day of the tenth month in the tenth year, the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, turn to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and prophesy against him and against all Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell him, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says:
I’m against you, Pharaoh, king of Egypt.
You are like a monster crocodile lying in the Nile River.
You say, “The Nile River is mine. I made it for myself.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘I will put hooks in your jaws
and make the fish in the Nile River stick to your scales.
I will pull you out of your river
with all the fish in the Nile sticking to your scales.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will leave you in the desert, you and all the fish from the Nile.
You will fall in an open field.
No one will pick you up or bury you.
I will feed you to wild animals and birds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then all those living in Egypt will know that I am the Lord.
Egypt, you have become like a broken walking stick
to the nation of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Israel grabbed you, you splintered and tore up their shoulders.
When they leaned on you, you broke, and they wrenched their backs.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I am going to attack you with a sword. I will kill people and animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Egypt will become a wasteland and a pile of rubble. Then you will know that I am the Lord. You said, “The Nile River is mine. I made it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why I’m against you and the Nile River. I will turn Egypt into a pile of rubble. It will become a wasteland, from Migdol to Syene, all the way to the border of Sudan.
speaker: Narrator

text: No human or animal will walk through it, and no one will live there for 40 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make Egypt the most desolate country in the world. For 40 years Egypt’s cities will lie in ruins. They will be ruined more than any other city. I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations and force them into other countries.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: After 40 years I will gather the Egyptians from the nations where they have been scattered.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring back the Egyptian captives and return them to Pathros, the land they came from. There they will be a weak kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will be the weakest kingdom, and they will never rule the nations again. I will make them so weak that they will never rule the nations again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The nation of Israel will never trust Egypt again. The people of Israel will remember how wrong they were whenever they turned to Egypt for help. Then they will know that I am the Almighty Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the first month in the twenty-seventh year, the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon made his army fight hard against Tyre. Every soldier’s head was worn bald, and every soldier’s shoulder was rubbed raw. Yet, he and his army got no reward for their hard-fought battle against Tyre.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Almighty Lord says: I’m going to give Egypt to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon. He will carry off its wealth, take its prized possessions, and loot it. That will be the pay for his army.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have given him Egypt as pay for what he has done. Nebuchadnezzar and his army worked for me, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On that day I will make the people of Israel strong again, and I will give you, Ezekiel, something to say among them. Then they will know that I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Son of man, prophesy. Say, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says:
Cry for that day!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The day is near. The day of the Lord is near.
It will be a gloomy day, a time of trouble for the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There will be war in Egypt and anguish in Ethiopia.
Many Egyptians will fall dead.
People will take away Egypt’s wealth,
and its foundations will be torn down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sudan, Put, Lud, all the Arabs, the Libyans,
and people from the promised land will die in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘This is what the Lord says:
All Egypt’s allies will die.
Egypt’s strength will disappear.
People will die in war from Migdol to Syene,
declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Egypt will become the most desolate country in the world, and Egypt’s cities will lie in ruins. They will be ruined more than other cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will know that I am the Lord, because I will set fire to Egypt and all her defenders will be killed.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day I will send messengers in ships to terrify those who live in safety in Sudan. The people of Sudan will be in anguish when Egypt is in trouble. That day is coming!
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I will use King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon to bring an end to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He and his troops, the most ruthless troops among the nations, will be brought to destroy the land. They will draw their swords to attack Egypt and fill the land with dead bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will dry up the Nile River and sell the land to wicked people. I will have foreigners destroy the land and everything in it. I, the Lord, have spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I will destroy the statues and put an end to the idols in Memphis. A prince will never rise again in Egypt. I will spread fear throughout Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will destroy Pathros, set fire to Zoan, and bring punishment on Thebes.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will pour out my fury on Sin, Egypt’s fortress, and I will kill many people in Thebes.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will set fire to Egypt. Sin will be in much pain. Thebes will be broken into pieces, and Memphis will be in trouble every day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The young men from Heliopolis and Bubastis will die in battle, and people from these cities will go into exile.
speaker: Narrator

text: At Tahpanhes the day will turn dark when I break Egypt’s power. Egypt’s strong army will be defeated. Clouds will cover Egypt, and people from its villages will go into exile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will know that I am the Lord, because I will bring punishment on Egypt.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day of the first month in the eleventh year, the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, I have broken the arm of Pharaoh, king of Egypt. His arm isn’t bandaged, so it can’t heal and be strong enough to hold a sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Almighty Lord says: I’m against Pharaoh, king of Egypt. I will break both his arms, the healthy one and the broken one. I will make the sword fall from his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations and force them into other countries.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make the arms of the king of Babylon strong. I will put my sword in his hand, but I will break Pharaoh’s arms. Pharaoh will groan like a person who is dying.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will strengthen the arms of the king of Babylon, but Pharaoh’s arms will fall. Then they will know that I am the Lord, because I will put my sword in the hand of the king of Babylon. He will strike Egypt with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations and force them into other countries. Then they will know that I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the third month in the eleventh year, the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Son of man, say to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and his many people,
‘Was there ever anyone as great as you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
What about Assyria?
It was a cedar in Lebanon
with fine branches that shaded the forest.
It was very tall.
Its top was among the clouds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Water made the tree grow,
and underground springs made it tall.
Rivers flowed around the place where the tree was planted.
Streams ran beside all the other trees around it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why it grew taller than all the other trees in the field.
Its branches became large and long because of so much water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the birds made their nests in its branches.
All the wild animals gave birth to their young under it.
All the powerful nations lived in its shade.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the tree was big and beautiful with its long branches.
Its roots reached down to many sources of water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The cedar trees in God’s garden couldn’t compare to it.
The pine trees couldn’t equal its branches.
The plane trees couldn’t measure up to its branches.
All the trees in God’s garden couldn’t match its beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was the one who made it beautiful with its many branches.
This tree was the envy of all the trees in Eden, in God’s garden.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: The tree grew very tall, and its top reached the clouds. It became arrogant because it was so tall.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I handed it over to a mighty ruler among the nations, and he surely dealt with it. I forced it out because of its wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Foreigners from the most ruthless nation cut it down and threw it away. Its branches fell on the mountains and in every valley. Its broken branches fell in every ravine in the land. All the nations in the world came out from under its shade and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the birds perched on the fallen tree, and all the wild animals lived in its branches.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the other trees growing by the water were kept from becoming arrogant because of their height, and their tops were no longer allowed to reach the clouds. So no tree, even if it is well-watered, will ever stand that tall. Every tree is going to die and go below the earth to join those who have died and gone down to the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: When the tree went down to the grave, I made people mourn. I covered the underground springs and held back the rivers. The many water sources stopped flowing. I made Lebanon mourn for the tree, and all the trees in the field fainted as they grieved over it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I made the nations tremble in fear at the sound of the tree’s crash. I brought the tree down to the grave to join those who had gone down to the pit. Then all the trees in Eden, the choicest and best trees of Lebanon, and all the trees that were well-watered were comforted below the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had gone down with the tree in the grave to join others killed in battle. All who lived in its shadow were scattered among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This tree is you, Pharaoh, and all your many people. No tree in Eden has ever been as honorable and as great as you. But you will be brought down below the earth with the trees of Eden. You will lie among the godless people who were killed in battle, declares the Almighty Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the twelfth month in the twelfth year, the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Son of man, sing a funeral song for Pharaoh, king of Egypt. Tell him,
‘You think you are like a lion among the nations.
Instead, you are like a crocodile in the water.
You splash around in the water.
You stir up the water with your feet.
You make the streams muddy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: When many nations gather together, I will spread my net over you, and they will haul you up in a net.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will throw you on the ground and toss you into an open field. I will make birds perch on you, and wild animals from all over the earth will feed on you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will scatter your flesh on the hills and fill the valleys with your rotting corpse.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will drench the earth with your flowing blood all the way to the mountains. Ravines will be filled with your dead body.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘When I put out your light, I will cover the sky and darken the stars. I will cover the sun with clouds, and the moon won’t shine anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will darken all the lights shining in the sky above you. I will bring darkness over your land, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘I will make many people troubled when I spread the news of your destruction among the nations to countries that you haven’t heard of.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many people will be shocked by what I will do to you. Their kings will shudder when I swing my sword in their faces. When you die, all of them will tremble in fear for their own lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: The sword of the king of Babylon will attack you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will cut down your people with the swords of warriors. All of them will be the most ruthless warriors among the nations. They will shatter the pride of Egypt and destroy its many people.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will also destroy all the animals beside its many water sources. The feet of humans and the hoofs of animals won’t stir up the water anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will make its water clear and make its streams flow like oil, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn Egypt into a wasteland. I will take everything in the land, and I will kill all the people who live there. Then they will know that I am the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is a funeral song. The people from the nations will sing this song. They will sing it as they mourn for Egypt and its many people,” declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fifteenth day of the month in the twelfth year, the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, cry for the many people of Egypt. Bring them down along with the other mighty nations. Send them down below the earth to be with those who have gone down to the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell them, ‘Are you more beautiful than anyone else? Go down and join the godless people.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Egyptians will lie among those who were killed in battle. A sword has been drawn. Drag Egypt and all its people away.
speaker: Narrator

text: The mightiest warriors will say to Pharaoh from the grave, ‘You and your defenders have come down, and you now lie with the godless people who were killed in battle.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Assyria is there with its whole army, and the graves of its soldiers are all around it. All of its soldiers are dead. They have been killed in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their graves are in the deepest parts of the pit. Assyria’s army lies around its grave. All of its soldiers are dead. They have been killed in battle. They once terrified people in the land of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Elam is there with all its soldiers, and the graves of its soldiers are all around it. All of its soldiers are dead. They have been killed in battle. They went down below the earth as godless people. They once terrified people in the land of the living. Now they suffer disgrace with those who have gone down to the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text: A bed has been made for Elam among the dead. The graves of its soldiers are all around it. The soldiers were godless people. They were killed in battle because they terrified others in the land of the living. Now they suffer disgrace with those who have gone down to the pit. They lie among the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Meshech and Tubal are there with all their soldiers, and the graves of their soldiers are all around them. Their soldiers were all godless people. They were killed in battle because they terrified others in the land of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: They don’t lie with the godless warriors who died and went down to the grave with their weapons of war. Their swords were placed under their heads. Their shields were placed on their bones because they terrified others in the land of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You Egyptians will be crushed with the godless people, and you will lie with those who were killed in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Edom is there with its kings and its princes. They used to be powerful, but now they lie with those who were killed in battle. They lie there with the godless people and with those who have gone down to the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All the rulers from the north and all the people from Sidon are there. They, too, went down with the dead. They are disgraced because they terrified people with their power. They were godless people. Now they lie with those who were killed in battle. They suffer disgrace with those who went down to the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Pharaoh and his army will see these things and be comforted over all the soldiers who have been killed in battle, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I terrified people in the land of the living. Pharaoh and all his soldiers will be laid among the godless people who were killed in battle,” declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, speak to your people. Tell them, ‘Suppose I bring war on this country, and the people of this country choose one of their men and make him their watchman.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he sees the enemy coming to attack the country, he will blow his horn to warn the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the people hear the horn and ignore the warning and the enemy comes and takes them, they will be responsible for their own deaths.
speaker: Narrator

text: They heard the sound of the horn but ignored its warning. So they are responsible for their own deaths. If they had taken the warning, they would have saved themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘But if the watchman sees the enemy coming and doesn’t blow his horn to warn the people and the enemy comes and kills someone, that watchman must die because of his sin. I will hold him responsible for their deaths.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, I have appointed you as a watchman for the people of Israel. Listen to what I say, and warn them for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose I say to a wicked person, ‘You wicked person, you will certainly die,’ and you say nothing to warn him to change his ways. That wicked person will die because of his sin, and I will hold you responsible for his death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you warn a wicked person to turn from his ways and he doesn’t turn from them, then he will die because of his sin. However, you will save yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, say to the people of Israel, ‘You have said this, “Our wickedness and our sins weigh us down, and we are rotting away because of them. How can we live?” ’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell them, ‘As I live, declares the Almighty Lord, I don’t want wicked people to die. Rather, I want them to turn from their ways and live. Change the way you think and act! Turn from your wicked ways! Do you want to die, people of Israel?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, say to your people, ‘The right things that a righteous person has done will not save him when he rebels. The wicked things that a wicked person has done will not make him stumble when he turns from his wickedness. The righteous person will not live when he sins.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I may promise the righteous person that he will certainly live. But if he trusts in the right things that he has done and he does evil, none of the right things that he has done will be remembered. He will die because of the evil things he has done.
speaker: Narrator

text: I may warn the wicked person that he will certainly die. But suppose he turns from his sin and does what is fair and right.
speaker: Narrator

text: He returns the security for a loan, pays back everything he stole, lives by the rules of life, and does nothing evil. Then he will certainly live. He will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: None of the sins that he has done will be remembered. He has done what is fair and right. He will certainly live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But your people say, ‘The Lord’s way is unfair.’ Yet, their ways are unfair.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the righteous person turns from the right things that he has done and does evil, he will die because of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the wicked person turns from his wickedness and does what is fair and right, he will live because of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet, the people of Israel say, ‘The Lord’s way is unfair.’ I will judge each of you by your own ways, people of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fifth day of the tenth month in the twelfth year of our captivity, a refugee from Jerusalem came to me. He said, “The city has been captured.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The evening before the refugee arrived, the power of the Lord came over me. On the morning the refugee arrived, the Lord made me speak. So I spoke, and I was no longer quiet.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, those who live in the ruined cities in Israel are saying, ‘Abraham was only one person, and he was given the land. But we are many. Certainly the land has been given to us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: You eat meat with blood in it. You look to your idols for help. You murder people. Should the land be given to you?
speaker: Narrator

text: You rely on your swords. You do disgusting things. You dishonor your neighbor’s wife. Should the land be given to you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: As I live, whoever is in the ruined cities will be killed in battle. Whoever is in the open field will become food for wild animals. Whoever is in fortified places and caves will die from plagues.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn the land into a barren wasteland. People will no longer brag about its power. The mountains of Israel will become so ruined that no one will travel through them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then people will know that I am the Lord, when I make the land a barren wasteland because of all the disgusting things that they have done.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, your people are talking about you by the walls and in the doorways of their homes. They are saying to each other, ‘Let’s go and hear the word that has come from the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they come to you, as if they are still my people, and they sit down in front of you. They listen to what you say, but they don’t do it. They say that they love me, but in their hearts they chase dishonest profits.
speaker: Narrator

text: To them you are nothing more than a singer with a beautiful voice who sings love songs or a musician who plays an instrument. They listen to your words, but they don’t do them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all your words come true—and they certainly will come true—these people will know that a prophet has been among them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, prophesy against the shepherds of Israel. Prophesy to these shepherds. Tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: How horrible it will be for the shepherds of Israel who have been taking care of only themselves. Shouldn’t shepherds take care of the sheep?
speaker: Narrator

text: You eat the best parts of the sheep, dress in the wool, and butcher the finest sheep. Yet, you don’t take care of the sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have not strengthened those that were weak, healed those that were sick, or bandaged those that were injured. You have not brought back those that strayed away or looked for those that were lost. You have ruled them harshly and violently.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they were scattered because there was no shepherd. When they were scattered, they became food for every wild animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: My sheep wandered over all the mountains and on every high hill. They were scattered throughout the whole earth. No one searched or looked for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘So, you shepherds, listen to the Lord’s word.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I live, declares the Almighty Lord, because there is no shepherd, my sheep have become prey. My sheep have become food for every wild animal. My shepherds haven’t searched for my sheep. They have taken care of only themselves, not my sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, you shepherds, listen to the Lord’s word.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Almighty Lord says: I am against the shepherds. I will demand that they hand over my sheep. I won’t let them take care of my sheep anymore, and they will no longer take care of only themselves. I will rescue my sheep from their mouths, and my sheep will no longer be their food.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I will search for my sheep myself, and I will look after them.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a shepherd looks after his flock when he is with his scattered sheep, so I will look after my sheep. I will rescue them on a cloudy and gloomy day from every place where they have been scattered.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring them out from the nations, gather them from the countries, and bring them to their own land. I will take care of them on the mountains of Israel, by the streams, and in all the inhabited places of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will feed them in good pasture, and they will graze on the mountains of Israel. They will rest on the good land where they graze, and they will feed on the best pastures in the mountains of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take care of my sheep and lead them to rest, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will look for those that are lost, bring back those that have strayed away, bandage those that are injured, and strengthen those that are sick. I will destroy those that are fat and strong. I will take care of my sheep fairly.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘As for you, my sheep, this is what the Almighty Lord says: I will judge disputes between one sheep and another, between rams and male goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t it enough for you to feed on the good pasture? Must you trample the rest of the pasture with your feet? You drink clean water. Must you muddy the rest of the water with your feet?
speaker: Narrator

text: Must my sheep eat what your feet have trampled and drink what your feet have muddied?
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘So this is what the Almighty Lord says to them: I will judge disputes between the fat sheep and the skinny sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: You fat sheep push the skinny sheep with your sides and shoulders, and you knock down all the sick sheep with your horns. You have scattered them all over.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I will rescue my sheep, and they will no longer be prey. I will judge between one sheep and another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will place one shepherd over them, my servant David, and he will take care of them. He will take care of them and be their shepherd.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, the Lord, will be their God, and my servant David will be their prince. I, the Lord, have spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘I will promise them peace. I will remove the wild animals from the land so that my sheep can live safely in the wilderness and sleep in the woods.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bless them and the places around my hill. I will send rain at the right time. These showers will be a blessing to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the trees in the field will produce fruit, the land will yield crops, and my sheep will live safely in their land. Then they will know that I am the Lord, because I will break off the bars on their yokes  and rescue them from the people who made them slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will no longer be prey to the nations, and the wild animals will no longer eat them. They will live safely, and no one will frighten them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give them a place that is known for its good crops. They will no longer experience hunger in the land, and they will no longer suffer the insults of other nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will know that I, the Lord their God, am with them and that they, the people of Israel, are my people, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You, my sheep, are the sheep in my pasture. You are mortal, and I am your God, declares the Almighty Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, turn to Mount Seir, and prophesy against it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell it, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says:
I’m against you, Mount Seir.
I will use my power against you,
and you will become a wasteland.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will turn your cities into ruins,
and you will become a wasteland.
Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘You have always been an enemy of Israel.
You deserted the people of Israel in battle
when they were in trouble during their final punishment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why, as I live, declares the Almighty Lord,
I will let you be murdered.
Murderers will pursue you.
Since you don’t hate murdering people, murder will pursue you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will turn Mount Seir into a barren wasteland,
and I will destroy everyone who comes or goes from there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will fill your mountains with those who have been killed.
Those killed in battle will fall on your hills
and in your valleys and ravines.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will turn you into a permanent wasteland.
Your cities will not be lived in.
Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘You said, “These two nations, Israel and Judah, along with their land, belong to us. We will take possession of them.” But the Lord was there.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why, as I live, declares the Almighty Lord, I will do to you what you did to them. When you were angry and jealous, you acted hatefully toward them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know that I, the Lord, heard all the insults that you spoke about the mountains of Israel. You said, “They have been deserted and handed over to us to use up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: You bragged and continually talked against me. I heard you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: The whole earth will be glad when I turn you into a wasteland.
speaker: Narrator

text: You were happy when the land of Israel became a wasteland. I will do the same thing to you. You will become a wasteland, Mount Seir, and so will all of Edom. Then you will know that I am the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “Son of man, prophesy to the mountains of Israel. Tell them, ‘Mountains of Israel, listen to the Lord’s word.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Almighty Lord says: Your enemies said this about you, “Aha! The ancient worship sites now belong to us.” ’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So prophesy. Say, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Your enemies turned you into ruins and crushed you from every side. You became the possession of the rest of the nations, and people began to talk and gossip about you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Mountains of Israel, listen to the Almighty Lord’s word. This is what the Almighty Lord says to the mountains and hills, to the ravines and valleys, and to the empty ruins and abandoned cities that have become prey and are mocked by the rest of the surrounding nations:
speaker: Narrator

text: In my fiery anger I have spoken against the rest of the nations and against all of Edom. The Edomites have taken possession of my land with wholehearted joy and with complete scorn. They forced out the people and took their land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So prophesy about Israel. Tell the mountains and hills and the ravines and valleys, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I am speaking in my anger and fury because you have been insulted by the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: So this is what the Almighty Lord says: I raise my hand and swear that the nations which surround you will be insulted.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘But you, mountains of Israel, will grow branches and bear fruit for my people Israel. My people will come home soon.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am for you. I will turn to you, and you will be plowed and planted.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will increase the number of people who live on you. All the people of Israel, all of them, will live on you. The cities will be inhabited, and the ruins will be rebuilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will increase the number of people and animals that live on you. They will grow and become many. I will let people live on you as in the past, and I will make you better off than ever before. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring people, my people Israel, to you. They will take possession of you, and you will be their inheritance. You will no longer take their children away from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: People say that you devour your people and take the children away from your nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you will no longer devour your people or take the children away from your nation, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will no longer let you hear the insults from the nations. You will no longer suffer the disgrace of the people. You will never again take the children away from your own nation, declares the Almighty Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, when the people of Israel lived in their land, they dishonored it by the way they lived and by everything they did. Their ways were as unclean  as a woman’s menstrual period.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I poured out my fury on them because they poured out blood on the land and they dishonored the land with their idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: I forced them into other nations, and they became scattered among the nations. I judged them based on the way that they lived and based on everything that they had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: But wherever they went among the nations, they dishonored my holy name. People said about them, ‘These are the Lord’s people, yet they had to leave his land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I became concerned about my holy name because my people dishonored it among the nations wherever they went.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So tell the people of Israel, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I am about to do something, people of Israel. I will not do this for your sake but for the sake of my holy name, which you have dishonored among the nations wherever you have gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will reveal the holiness of my great name, which has been dishonored by the nations, the name that you have dishonored among them. Then the nations will know that I am the Lord, because I will reveal my holiness among you as they watch, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘I will take you from the nations and gather you from every country. I will bring you back to your own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will sprinkle clean water on you and make you clean  instead of unclean. Then I will cleanse you from all your idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give you a new heart and put a new spirit in you. I will remove your stubborn hearts and give you obedient hearts.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will put my Spirit in you. I will enable you to live by my laws, and you will obey my rules.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will live in the land that I gave your ancestors. You will be my people, and I will be your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will rescue you from all your uncleanness. I will make the grain grow so that you will never again have famines.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make fruit grow on the trees and crops grow in the fields so that you will no longer suffer disgrace among the nations because of famines.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will remember your evil ways and the bad things that you did, and you will hate yourselves for all these wicked and disgusting things.
speaker: Narrator

text: I want you to know that I’m not doing this for your sake, declares the Almighty Lord. Be ashamed and disgraced because of your ways, people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: On the day that I cleanse you from all your wickedness, I will cause your cities to be lived in again, and your ruins will be rebuilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wasteland will be plowed. It will no longer remain empty for everyone passing by to see.
speaker: Narrator

text: People will say, “This wasteland has become like the garden of Eden. The cities were destroyed. They were empty and ruined, but now they are fortified and have people living in them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The surrounding nations that are left will know that I, the Lord, have rebuilt the ruined places and planted crops in the land that was empty. I, the Lord, have spoken, and I will do it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Almighty Lord says: I will also let the people of Israel ask me to make them as numerous as sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will be like the sheep for sacrifices, like the sheep in Jerusalem during the appointed festivals. Their ruined cities will be filled with flocks of people. Then they will know that I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The power of the Lord came over me. The Lord brought me out by his Spirit and put me down in the middle of a valley. The valley was filled with bones.
speaker: Narrator
