text: He led me all around them. I saw that there were very many bones at the bottom of the valley, and they were very dry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he asked me, “Son of man, can these bones live?”
I answered, “Only you know, Almighty Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me, “Prophesy to these bones. Tell them, ‘Dry bones, listen to the Lord’s word.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Almighty Lord says to these bones: I will cause breath to enter you, and you will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will put ligaments on you, place muscles on you, and cover you with skin. I will put breath in you, and you will live. Then you will know that I am the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I prophesied as I was commanded. While I was prophesying, suddenly there was a rattling noise, and the bones came together, one bone attaching itself to another.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I looked, I saw that ligaments were on them, muscles were on them, and skin covered them. Yet, there was no breath in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, “Prophesy to the breath!  Prophesy, son of man. Tell the breath, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Come from the four winds, Breath, and breathe on these people who were killed so that they will live.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I prophesied as he commanded me, and the breath entered them. Then they came to life and stood on their feet. There were enough of them to form a very large army.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord also said to me, “Son of man, all the people of Israel are like these bones. The people say, ‘Our bones are dry, and our hope has vanished. We are completely destroyed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So prophesy. Tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: My people, I will open your graves and take you out of them. I will bring you to Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, my people, you will know that I am the Lord, because I will open your graves and bring you out of your graves.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will put my Spirit in you, and you will live. I will place you in your own land. Then you will know that I, the Lord, have spoken, and I have done it, declares the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me again. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, take a stick and write on it: ‘For Judah and for the Israelites who are associated with it.’ Then take another stick and write on it, ‘The stick of Ephraim, for Joseph and for all the people of Israel associated with it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then join both sticks together so that they will be one in your hand. Your people will say to you,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Tell us what you mean by this.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then say to them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I will take Joseph’s stick, which is in Ephraim’s hand, and the tribes of Israel associated with it, and I will put them with Judah’s stick. I will make them into one stick. They will be one in my hand.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When you hold the sticks in your hand, let the people see them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then tell them, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I will take the Israelites out of the nations where they’ve gone. I will gather them from everywhere and bring them to their own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will form them into one nation in the land on the mountains of Israel. One king will rule all of them. They will no longer be two nations or be divided into two kingdoms.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will no longer dishonor themselves with their idols, with their detestable things, or with their rebellious acts. I will forgive them for all the times they turned away from me and sinned. I will cleanse them so that they will be my people, and I will be their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘My servant David will be their king, and all of them will have one shepherd. They will live by my rules, and they will obey my laws.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will live in the land that I gave my servant Jacob, the land where their ancestors lived. They, their children, and their grandchildren will live in it permanently. My servant David will always be their prince.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will promise them peace. This promise  will last forever. I will establish them, make them increase in number, and put my holy place among them permanently.
speaker: Narrator

text: My dwelling place will be with them. I will be their God, and they will be my people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the nations will know that I, the Lord, have set Israel apart as holy, because my holy place will be among them permanently.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, turn to Gog from the land of Magog. He is the chief prince of the nations of Meshech and Tubal. Prophesy against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell him, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I am against you, Gog, chief prince of Meshech and Tubal.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn you around and put hooks in your jaws. I will lead you out with all your military forces, with horses and riders. Your soldiers will be fully armed. They will carry large and small shields and be able to use swords.
speaker: Narrator

text: Persia, Sudan, and Put will be with you. They, too, will have shields and helmets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gomer will come with all its troops and with the nation of Togarmah from the far north. There will be many armies with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Be prepared! Be prepared, you and all the soldiers assembled around you. You will be their leader.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a long time you will be called to service. In the years to come, you will attack a land that has been rebuilt after a war. Its people have been gathered from many nations and brought to the mountains of Israel, mountains that have been ruined for a long time. These people were brought there from the nations, and all of them live there safely.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will attack like a storm and cover the land like a cloud. Your troops and the many armies will be with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: At that time ideas will enter your head, and you will make wicked plans.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will say, “I’ll attack a land with unwalled villages. I will attack peaceful people who live safely. All of them live without walls, locks, or gates.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will come to rob them and loot them. I will use my power against the ruins that people are living in again. I will use it against the people who were gathered from the nations. These people have cattle and property, and they live in the world.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Sheba, Dedan, the merchants from Tarshish, and all their villages will ask you, “Did you come to rob these people of their possessions? Did you assemble all these soldiers to carry away large amounts of silver and gold and to take cattle and property?” ’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So prophesy, son of man. Tell Gog, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: At that time my people Israel will live safely, and you will know it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will come from your place in the far north and many armies will be with you. All of you will ride on horses. You will be a large crowd and a mighty army.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will attack my people Israel like a cloud that covers the land. In the days to come, I will let you attack my land so that nations will know me. I will use you for my holy purpose as they watch.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: You are the one I spoke about long ago through my servants the prophets of Israel. They prophesied in those days that I would bring you to attack them.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day that Gog attacks the land of Israel, I will be filled with burning anger, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In my fiery anger I tell you this. On that day there will be a large earthquake in the land of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fish, birds, wild animals, everything that crawls on the ground, and every person on earth will tremble in my presence. The mountains will be torn down, the cliffs will crumble, and every wall will fall to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will declare war against Gog on all my mountains, declares the Almighty Lord. Each person will use his sword against his relative.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will punish Gog with plagues and death. I will send rainstorms, large hailstones, fire, and burning sulfur on his troops and on the many armies with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will show my greatness and my holiness. I will reveal myself to many nations. Then they will know that I am the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “Son of man, prophesy against Gog. Tell it, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I am against you, Gog, the chief prince of Meshech and Tubal.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn you around and lead you. I will bring you from the far north and have you attack the mountains of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will knock the bow out of your left hand and make you drop the arrows in your right hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will die on the mountains of Israel with your troops and the armies that are with you. I will let you become food for every bird of prey and for every wild animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will die in the open field because I said so, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send fire on Magog and on those who live safely on the coasts. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make my holy name known among my people Israel, and I will never let them dishonor my holy name again. Then the nations will know that I am the Lord, the Holy One in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘It’s coming! It will happen! declares the Almighty Lord. This is the day I have spoken about.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those living in the cities of Israel will go out. They will set fire to weapons and burn them. They will burn small and large shields, bows and arrows, and war clubs and spears. They will burn them for seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will not need to get wood from the field or cut down trees in the woods. They will make fires with the weapons. They will loot those who looted them, and they will grab things back from those who grabbed their things, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘When that day comes, I will give Gog a burial place in Israel. It will be in Travelers Valley, east of the Dead Sea. It will block those who travel through the valley. Gog and his whole army will be buried there. So it will be called the valley of Gog’s troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel will be burying them there for seven months to make the land clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the common people will be burying them. The people of Israel will be honored on the day of my victory, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘People will be chosen to go through the land and make it clean. With the help of others they will bury the dead soldiers that are still on the ground. At the end of seven months they will begin their search.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever they go through the land and see a human bone, they will set up a marker beside it until the grave diggers have buried that bone in the valley of Gog’s troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: (A city named Hamonah  will also be there.) In this way they will cleanse the land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, this is what the Almighty Lord says: Tell every kind of bird and every wild animal, ‘Assemble, and come together from all around for the sacrifice that I’m preparing for you. It will be a huge feast on the mountains of Israel. You can eat meat and drink blood there.
speaker: Narrator

text: You can eat the meat of warriors and drink the blood of the princes of the earth. All of them will be killed like rams, lambs, goats, bulls and all the best animals of Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: You can eat the best meat until you are full and drink blood until you are drunk at the sacrifice that I am preparing for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: At my table you will be filled with horses and riders, warriors, and soldiers of every kind, declares the Almighty Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will show my greatness among the nations. All the nations will see how I will turn my power against them to punish them.
speaker: Narrator

text: From that day on, the people of Israel will know that I am the Lord their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the nations will know that the people of Israel went into captivity because they did wrong and rebelled against me. So I hid my face from them and handed them over to their enemies. They were killed in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: I paid them back for their uncleanness and their sins, and I hid my face from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So this is what the Almighty Lord says: Now I will bring back Jacob’s captives and have compassion for the whole nation of Israel. I will stand up for my holy name.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they live safely in a land where no one will frighten them, they will forget their shame and all the unfaithful things they have done against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring them back from the other nations and gather them from the countries of their enemies. Many nations will see that I am holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then my people will know that I am the Lord their God. I sent them into captivity among the nations, and I brought them back again to their land. I left none of them behind.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will no longer hide my face from them, because I will pour out my Spirit on the nation of Israel, declares the Almighty Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It was the tenth day of the month in the beginning of the twenty-fifth year of our captivity and fourteen years after Jerusalem was captured. At that time the Lord’s power came over me, and he brought me to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: In visions, God brought me to Israel and set me down on a very high mountain. On the south side of the mountain were some buildings that looked like those in a city.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought me closer. I saw a man who looked like he was covered with bronze. The man was holding a linen tape measure and a measuring stick, and he stood in a gateway.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, look with your eyes, and listen with your ears. Pay close attention to everything I’m going to show you. You were brought here to be shown these things. Tell the nation of Israel everything that you see.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw a wall that surrounded the temple. The man had a measuring stick that was 10½ feet long. He measured the wall. It was 10½ feet thick and 10½ feet high.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man went to the gateway that faced east. He went up its steps and measured the entrance to the gateway. It was 10½ feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were also guardrooms. Each guardroom was 10½ feet long and 10½ feet wide. The space between the guardrooms was 9 feet thick. And the entrance to the gateway by the entrance hall of the temple was 10½ feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also measured the entrance hall of the gateway.
speaker: Narrator

text: It extended 14 feet from the temple. Its recessed walls were 3½ feet thick. The gateway’s entrance hall faced the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, there were three guardrooms on each side of the eastern gateway. All three rooms on each side were the same size, and the recessed walls on each side were the same size.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man measured the width of the entrance to the gateway. It was 17½ feet wide, and the gateway was 23 feet long.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a barrier about 21 inches in front of each guardroom. The guardrooms were 10½ feet square.
speaker: Narrator

text: He measured the gateway from the top of one guardroom to the top of the opposite guardroom. It was 44 feet wide from one door to the opposite door.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also measured the entrance hall. It was 35 feet wide. In front of the entrance hall to the gateway was a courtyard on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total length of the gateway from the front of the outer part to the front of the inner part of the entrance hall was 87½ feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: The guardrooms and recessed walls inside the gateway had small windows all around. The entrance hall also had windows all around on the inside. Pictures of palm trees were carved on the recessed walls.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man brought me into the outer courtyard. I saw rooms there and pavement all around the courtyard. There were 30 rooms along the edge of the pavement.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pavement in the lower courtyard ran alongside the gateways. It was as wide as it was long.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man measured the distance from the inside of the lower gateway to the outside of the inner courtyard. It was 175 feet from east to north.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man measured the length and width of the gateway, leading to the outer courtyard. This was the gateway that faced north.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its three guardrooms, its recessed walls, and its entrance hall were the same size as those in the east gateway. The gateway was 87½ feet long and 44 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its windows, recessed walls, and palm tree pictures were the same size as those in the east gateway. Seven steps went up to it and led to its entrance hall.
speaker: Narrator

text: The inner courtyard had a gateway opposite the north gate just like the east gateway. The man measured the distance from one gate to the other gate. It was 175 feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man led me to the south side, and I saw a gateway that faced south. He measured its recessed walls and its entrance hall. They were the same size as those of the other gateways.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gateway and its entrance hall had windows on all sides like the windows in the other gateways. It was 87½ feet long and 44 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven steps went up to it and led to its entrance hall. Pictures of palm trees were carved on the recessed walls, one picture on each side.
speaker: Narrator

text: The inner courtyard had a gateway facing south. The man measured the distance from the gateway on the south side to its opposite gateway. It was 175 feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man brought me to the inner courtyard through the south gateway. He measured the south gateway. It was the same size as the others.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its guardrooms, recessed walls, and entrance hall were the same size as the other gateways. The guardrooms and the entrance hall had windows all around. The gateway was 87½ feet long and 44 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were entrance halls all around the inner courtyard. They were all 44 feet long and 9 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entrance halls faced the outer courtyard. Pictures of palm trees were carved on the recessed walls, and eight steps led up to each gateway.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man brought me to the east side of the inner courtyard. He measured the gateway. It was the same size as the others.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its guardrooms, recessed walls, and entrance halls were the same size as those of the other gateways. Its guardrooms and entrance hall had windows all around. The gateway was 87½ feet long and 44 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its entrance hall faced the outer courtyard. Pictures of palm trees were carved on the recessed walls, and eight steps led up to the gateway.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man brought me to the north gateway. He measured it. It was the same size as the others.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its guardrooms, recessed walls, and entrance hall had windows all around. The gateway was 87½ feet long and 44 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its recessed walls faced the outer courtyard. Pictures of palm trees were carved on the recessed walls, and eight steps led up to the gateway.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a room with a door that opened toward the entrance hall of the gateway. This is the room where the priests washed the animals for the burnt offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the entrance hall of the gateway there were two tables on each side of the room. On these tables the animals were slaughtered for burnt offerings, offerings for sin, and guilt offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: On each side of the entrance to the north gateway there were two tables, and on the other side of the entrance hall of the gateway there were two tables.
speaker: Narrator

text: So there were four tables on each side of the gateway, eight tables in all, on which they slaughtered animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were four tables made of cut stone for burnt offerings. They were 3 feet long, 3 feet wide, and 21 inches high. On these tables the priests laid the utensils that were used to slaughter animals for burnt offerings and sacrifices.
speaker: Narrator

text: Double-pronged hooks, three inches long, were attached to the wall all around the room, and the tables were for the meat of the animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Outside the gateways to the inner courtyard were the rooms for the singers in the inner courtyards. One room was at the side of the north gateway. It faced south. The other room was at the side of the south gateway. It faced north.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man said to me, “This room that faces south is for the priests who serve in the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The room that faces north is for the priests who serve at the altar. These priests are Zadok’s descendants. They are the only Levites who are able to come near the Lord and serve him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man measured the courtyard. It was a perfect square—175 feet long and 175 feet wide. And the altar was in front of the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man brought me to the entrance hall of the temple and measured its recessed walls. They were 9 feet on each side. The gateway was 24½ feet wide, and the walls on each side were 5 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entrance hall was 35 feet long and 21 feet wide. Steps led up to it. Pillars stood by the recessed walls, one on each side of the entrance hall.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man brought me into the holy place in the temple and measured the recessed walls. They were 10½ feet wide on each side.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entrance was 17½ feet wide, and on each side of the entrance the walls were 9 feet wide. Then he measured the length of the holy place. It was 70 feet long and 35 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man went inside and measured the passageway. It was 3½ feet thick. The entrance was 10½ feet high and 12 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he measured the room at the end of the holy place. It was 35 feet long and 35 feet wide. The man said to me, “This is the most holy place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Next, the man measured the temple wall. It was 10½ feet wide. The width of each side room around the temple was 7 feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rooms were arranged on three different stories. There were 30 rooms on each story. These rooms had supports all the way around the temple wall, but these supports were not fastened to the temple wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: The side rooms grew wider all the way around as they went up, story after story. The surrounding structure went from story to story all around the temple. The structure grew wider as it went higher. A stairway went from the first story through the second story to the third story.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also saw a raised base all around the temple. This base was the foundation for the side rooms. It measured the full length of the measuring rod, 10½ feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: The outer wall of the side rooms was 9 feet thick. There was an open area between the side rooms connected to the temple
speaker: Narrator

text: and the priests’ rooms. It was 35 feet wide and went all around the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The doors in the side rooms were entrances into the open area. There was one door to the north and another to the south. The base of the open area was 9 feet wide all the way around.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the far end of the open area, on the west side of the temple, was a building 122½ feet wide. The wall of the building was 9 feet thick all the way around, and it was 157½ feet long.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man measured the temple. It was 175 feet long. This included the open area with the building and its walls. All together it was 175 feet long.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eastern side of the temple, including the open area, was also 175 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He also measured the length of the building facing the courtyard on the west side along with its corridors on both sides. It was 175 feet long.
The holy place and the most holy place were paneled.
speaker: Narrator

text: The doorposts, the small windows, and the corridors of all three stories were paneled. The walls, from the floor up to the windows, were paneled.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the space above the door to the most holy place and on the walls all around it,
speaker: Narrator

text: there were pictures of angels  and palm trees. Palm trees were positioned between each of the angels, and each angel had two faces:
speaker: Narrator

text: the face of a man, which was turned toward a palm tree on one side, and the face of a lion, which was turned toward a palm tree on the other side. These pictures were carved all around the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pictures of angels and palm trees were carved on the walls from the floor to the space above the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: The doorframes in the holy place were square. In front of the most holy place was something similar.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a wooden altar, 5 feet high and 3½ feet wide. Its corners, its base, and its sides were made of wood. Then the man told me, “This is the table that is in the presence of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The holy place and the most holy place had two doors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of the doors were double doors that swung open.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pictures of angels and palm trees were carved on the doors of the holy place as on the walls. There was a wooden roof hanging over the outer entrance hall.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were small windows and palm trees on both sides of the entrance hall, on the side rooms of the temple, and on the roofs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man led me out toward the north to the outer courtyard. He brought me to the side rooms opposite both the open area and the northern building.
speaker: Narrator

text: The building that faced north was 175 feet long and 87½ feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: Opposite the inner courtyard was an area that was 35 feet wide, and opposite the pavement of the outer courtyard were corridors facing corridors on all three stories.
speaker: Narrator

text: In front of the side rooms was a walkway, 17½ feet wide and 175 feet long. The doors of these side rooms faced north.
speaker: Narrator

text: The side rooms on the third story were narrower than those on the first or second stories of the building because the corridors took space away from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rooms were in three stories. They didn’t have pillars like the pillars in the courtyards. That is why the rooms on the third story were set farther back than those on the first and second stories.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a wall which ran parallel to the side rooms and the outer courtyard. It ran alongside the side rooms for 87½ feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: The row of rooms in the outer courtyard was 87½ feet long. The rooms that faced the temple were 175 feet long.
speaker: Narrator

text: These lower side rooms had an entrance on the east side. A person was able to enter the outer courtyard through them.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were side rooms parallel to the wall of the courtyard on the south side. They faced the open area and the building.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a walkway in front of them like the one that was in front of the side rooms on the north side. These side rooms were as long and as wide as the northern rooms. They had the same exits, dimensions, and doors.
speaker: Narrator

text: The doors to the south rooms were the same as the doors to the north rooms. There was a doorway at the other end of the walkway that was parallel to the corresponding wall that ran eastward. People entered through that doorway.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man said to me, “The northern and southern side rooms that face the open area are holy rooms. These rooms are where the priests who come near the Lord eat the holiest offerings. Because these rooms are holy, the priests keep the holiest offerings there: the grain offerings, the offerings for sin, and the guilt offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once the priests enter the holy place, they must not go out of the holy place into the outer courtyard until they leave behind the clothes that they wore as they served. These clothes are holy. The priests must put on other clothes. Then they can go into the area that is for the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the man had finished measuring the inner part of the temple area, he led me out through the east gate. Then he measured all the way around the outer area.
speaker: Narrator

text: He measured the east side with a measuring stick. It was 875 feet long according to the measuring stick.
speaker: Narrator

text: He measured the north side. It was 875 feet long according to the measuring stick.
speaker: Narrator

text: He measured the south side. It was 875 feet long according to the measuring stick.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came around to the west side and measured it. It was 875 feet long according to the measuring stick.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he measured all four sides. There was a wall all around it. The wall was 875 feet long and 875 feet wide. It separated what was holy from what was unholy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man took me to the east gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw the glory of the God of Israel coming from the east. His voice was like the sound of rushing water, and the earth was shining because of his glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: This vision was like the one I saw when he came  to destroy Jerusalem and like the one I saw by the Chebar River. I immediately bowed down.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s glory came into the temple through the east gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit lifted me and brought me into the inner courtyard. I saw the Lord’s glory fill the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: I heard someone speaking to me from inside the temple while the man was standing beside me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The voice said to me, “Son of man, this is the place where my throne is and the place where my feet rest. This is where I will live among the Israelites forever. Then the people of Israel and their kings will no longer dishonor my holy name by acting like prostitutes, nor will they dishonor it with the dead bodies of their kings.
speaker: Narrator

text: They put their doorway by my doorway and their doorposts by my doorposts. Only a wall separated me from them. They dishonored my holy name because of the disgusting things that they have done. So I destroyed them in my anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now they must stop acting like prostitutes and take the dead bodies of their kings far away from me. Then I will live among them forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, describe this temple to the people of Israel. Then they will be ashamed because of their sins. Let them study the plans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose they are ashamed of everything that they have done. Then show them the design of the temple, its arrangements, its exits and entrances—its entire design. Tell them about all its rules and regulations. Then write these things down for them so that they can remember its design and follow all its rules.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is a regulation of the temple: The whole area all the way around the top of the mountain is most holy. Yes, this is a regulation of the temple.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the measurements of the altar, using royal measurements. (The royal measuring stick was 21 inches long.) The base of the altar was 21 inches high and 21 inches wide. All around the edge of the altar was a rim measuring 9 inches wide. This was the height of the altar:
speaker: Narrator

text: From the base on the ground to the lower ledge it was 3½ feet high, and from the lower ledge to the upper ledge it was 7 feet high and 21 inches wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: The place where the sacrifices were burned was 7 feet high. There were four horns above it.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was square, 21 feet wide and 21 feet long.
speaker: Narrator

text: The upper ledge was also square. It was 24½ feet long and 24½ feet wide. It had a rim all the way around that was 10½ inches wide. Its base was 21 inches. The steps to the altar faced east.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man said to me, “Son of man, this is what the Almighty Lord says: These are the rules for sacrificing burnt offerings and for sprinkling blood on the altar after the altar is built.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give a young bull to the priests as an offering for sin. These priests are Zadok’s descendants, men from the tribe of Levi, who can come near me and serve me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take some of the bull’s blood, and put it on the altar’s four horns, on the four corners of the ledge, and on the rim all the way around the altar. When you do this, you will remove sin from the altar and make peace with the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then take a young bull as an offering for sin, and burn it in the place appointed near the temple, outside the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the second day bring a male goat that has no defects as an offering for sin. Remove sin from the altar as you did with the young bull.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you finish removing sin, offer a young bull and a ram that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer them to the Lord. The priests must throw salt on them and offer them as burnt offerings to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every day for seven days you must sacrifice a goat, a young bull, and a ram from the flock as an offering for sin. They must be animals that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days the priests should make peace with the Lord at the altar, purify it, and consecrate it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When those days are over, on the eighth day, the priests must sacrifice burnt offerings and fellowship offerings on the altar. Then I will accept them, declares the Almighty Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man took me back to the outer east gate of the holy place, and the gate was shut.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to me, “This gate will stay shut and will not be opened. No one may enter through it because the Lord God of Israel entered through it. It must be kept shut.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only the prince may sit there and eat food in the presence of the Lord. He will enter through the entrance hall of the gateway and leave the same way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man brought me through the north gate in front of the temple. When I looked, I saw the Lord’s glory fill the Lord’s temple. I immediately bowed down.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to me, “Son of man, pay close attention. Look, and listen to everything I’m going to tell you. Listen to all the rules and regulations for the Lord’s temple. Pay close attention to everyone who enters the temple and leaves from the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell the rebellious people of Israel, ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I’ve had enough of all the disgusting things that you have done, people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: You brought godless foreigners  into my holy place. You dishonored my temple when you offered fat and blood to me. You rejected my promise so that you could do all your disgusting things.
speaker: Narrator

text: You didn’t take care of my holy things. You put foreigners in charge of my temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: So this is what the Almighty Lord says: Any godless foreigner who lives among the Israelites may not enter my holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Some Levites went far away from me when Israel wandered off to follow their idols. They must be punished for their sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: They could have served in my holy place. They could have guarded the gates of the temple. They could have served in the temple by slaughtering the animals for the burnt offerings and the sacrifices for the people. They could have stood in front of the people and served them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they served the people by standing in front of their idols and by making Israel fall into sin. So I raised my hand and swore that they would be punished for their sins, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must not come near me and serve me as priests. They must not come near any of my holy things or my most holy things. They must suffer disgrace because of the disgusting things that they have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will assign them all of the less important work in the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘But the priests who are Levites and descendants of Zadok took care of my holy place when the Israelites wandered away from me. They may come near me and serve me, and they may stand in my presence. They may bring fat and blood to me, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They may enter my holy place, come near my table to serve me, and take care of everything I gave them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they enter the gateways to the inner courtyard, they must wear linen clothes. They must have no wool on them while they serve in the gateways to the inner courtyard and in the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must wear linen turbans on their heads and linen undergarments. They must not wear anything that makes them sweat.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they go out among the people in the outer courtyard, they must take off the clothes that they wore as they served. They must leave their clothes in the side rooms of the holy place and put on other clothes so that they do not transfer the holiness from their clothes to the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘They must not shave their heads or let their hair grow long. They must keep the hair on their heads trimmed.
speaker: Narrator

text: None of the priests may drink wine when they enter the inner courtyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must not marry widows or women who have been divorced. They may marry only virgins from the nation of Israel or widows of priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must teach my people the difference between what is holy and what is unholy. They must show the people how to tell the difference between what is clean and what is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all disputes the priests must act as judges and make decisions based on my laws. They must obey my rules and my regulations at all my festivals. They must observe holy days to worship me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘A priest must not make himself unclean by going near a dead body. But a priest may become unclean if the dead person is his father, mother, son, daughter, brother, or unmarried sister.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a priest is made clean, he must wait seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he enters the inner courtyard of the holy place to serve in the holy place, he must bring his offering for sin, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘The priests will have no inheritance. I am their inheritance. Don’t give them any possessions in Israel. The priests belong to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will eat grain offerings, offerings for sin, and guilt offerings. Everything in Israel that is devoted to the Lord will belong to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests should have the best of all the first ripened fruits. The best of every gift from all your contributions must go to the priests. The best of your dough must go to the priests. This will cause a blessing to rest on your home.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests must never eat any bird or animal that has died naturally or was killed by other wild animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Divide the land by drawing lots for the property you will inherit. Set aside an area 43,750 feet long and 35,000 feet wide for the Lord. The entire area will be holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: An area of 875 feet square will be for the holy place with an open area 87½ feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: Measure off an area 43,750 feet long and 17,500 feet wide. The holy place, that is, the most holy place, will be in this area.
speaker: Narrator

text: This holy part of the land will belong to the priests who serve in the holy place, the priests who come near to serve the Lord. They will use this place for their homes, and it will be the location for the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: An area 43,750 feet long and 17,500 feet wide will belong to the Levites who serve in the temple. It will be given to them so that they have cities to live in.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘You must designate an area 8,750 feet wide and 43,750 feet long as the city’s property. It will be located alongside the holy area. It will belong to all the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘The prince will have all the land on both sides of the holy area and on both sides of the property belonging to the city. From the western boundary of the holy area, his land will extend to the Mediterranean Sea. From the eastern boundary of the holy area, his land will extend to the eastern border of the country. His territory will be as large as the territory of one of the tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: This land will belong to the prince in Israel. Then my princes will no longer oppress my people. They will give land to each tribe of the nation of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: I’ve had enough of you, you princes of Israel. Stop your violence and looting, and do what is fair and right. Stop evicting my people, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must have honest scales and honest dry and liquid measures.
speaker: Narrator

text: The dry and liquid measures must always be the same: The ephah and the bath should hold the same as one-tenth of a homer. The homer must be the standard measure.
speaker: Narrator

text: One shekel must weigh 20 gerahs. One mina must weigh 60 shekels.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is the contribution you must give to the Lord: seventeen percent of your wheat and seventeen percent of your barley.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must give one percent of your olive oil using the standard measure.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must take one sheep out of every 200 from the well-watered pastures of Israel. You must sacrifice them with grain offerings, burnt offerings, and fellowship offerings to make peace with the Lord, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the common people must give this contribution to the prince in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prince is responsible to provide burnt offerings, grain offerings, and wine offerings at the annual festivals, the New Moon Festivals, the weekly days of rest—holy days, and all the other appointed festivals of the nation of Israel. He must prepare offerings for sin, grain offerings, burnt offerings, and fellowship offerings to make peace with the Lord for the nation of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: On the first day of the first month, take a young bull that has no defects and remove sin from the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must take some blood from the offering for sin and put it on the doorposts of the temple, on the four corners of the ledge of the altar, and on the doorposts of the gateways of the inner courtyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must do the same on the seventh day of the month for everyone who unintentionally does something wrong and is unaware of it. So you must make peace with the Lord for the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘On the fourteenth day of the first month, you will celebrate the Passover, a festival lasting seven days when unleavened bread is eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the prince must prepare for himself and for all the common people a young bull as an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every day during the seven days of the festival, he must prepare burnt offerings for the Lord: seven young bulls that have no defects, seven rams that have no defects, and one male goat as an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must also give as a grain offering a half-bushel for each young bull and a half-bushel for each ram. He must also give one gallon of olive oil for every half-bushel of grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, at the Festival of Booths, he must do the same as on those seven days. He must prepare the same offerings for sin, burnt offerings, grain offerings, and olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: The east gate of the inner courtyard must be closed during the six working days, but it must be opened on the weekly day of rest—a holy day. It must also be opened on the New Moon Festival.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prince must enter from the outside through the entrance hall of the gateway. He must stand by the doorposts of the gateway. Then the priests must prepare the prince’s burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. He must worship at the entrance of the gateway and then leave. The gate must not be closed until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: The common people must worship at the door of the gateway in the presence of the Lord on the weekly days of rest—holy days, and on New Moon Festivals.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prince must offer to the Lord six lambs that have no defects and one ram that has no defects as a burnt offering on the day of rest—a holy day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The grain offering that is to be brought with the ram must be a half-bushel, and the grain offering that is to be brought with the lambs must be whatever the prince can bring. One gallon of olive oil must be brought with each half-bushel of grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the month, the burnt offering must be one young bull, six lambs, and one ram—all animals that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: With each young bull and each ram the offering must include a half-bushel of grain, and with each lamb the offering must be whatever the prince wants to bring. One gallon of olive oil must be offered with each half-bushel of grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the prince enters, he must enter through the entrance hall of the gateway. He must enter and leave the same way.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘The people will enter the Lord’s presence at the time of the appointed festivals. Those entering through the north gate to worship must leave through the south gate. Those entering through the south gate must leave through the north gate. They must not leave through the same gate they entered. They must leave through the opposite gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prince must be among them. When they enter, he must enter. When they leave, he must leave.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘On festival days and at appointed festivals, a grain offering of a half-bushel must be brought with each young bull, and a half-bushel must be brought with each ram. But with the lambs, the prince may bring whatever he wants to bring. One gallon of olive oil must be brought with each half-bushel of grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the prince prepares a freewill burnt offering, either a burnt offering or a fellowship offering to the Lord, the east gate must be opened for him. He must sacrifice burnt offerings and fellowship offerings as he does on the day of rest—a holy day. When he leaves, the gate must be shut after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Prepare a year-old lamb that has no defects every day as a burnt offering to the Lord. Do this every morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, prepare a grain offering with it every morning: three-and-a-third quarts of grain and one-and-a-third quarts of olive oil to moisten the flour. It will be a grain offering dedicated to the Lord. These rules are to be followed always.
speaker: Narrator

text: Prepare the lamb, the grain offering, and the olive oil every morning as a daily burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘This is what the Almighty Lord says: Suppose the prince offers one of his sons a gift from his property. The gift will belong to his descendants because it is their inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: But suppose the prince offers a gift from his property to one of his servants. The gift will belong to the servant only until the year of freedom. Then the gift will go back to the prince. Only his sons can inherit his property.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prince must not take any of the people’s property. He must not force them to give up their property. He must give his own property as an inheritance to his sons so that none of my people will be separated from their property.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man brought me through a passage beside the gateway to the side rooms that faced north. These rooms were reserved for the priests. He showed me a place on the west side of the rooms.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “This is the place where the priests must boil the meat for the guilt offering and the offering for sin. This is the place where they must bake grain offerings so that they don’t have to bring the offerings into the outer courtyard. This way they won’t transfer holiness to the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man led me to the outer courtyard and took me past the four corners of the courtyard. I saw that in each corner of the courtyard there was a smaller courtyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: The smaller courtyards that were in each of the four corners of the courtyard were 60 feet long and 45 feet wide. All four of the smaller courtyards in the corners of the courtyard were the same size.
speaker: Narrator

text: Around each of the four courtyards were stone walls, and these walls were equipped with fireplaces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man said to me, “These are the kitchens where the temple servants must boil the people’s sacrifices.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man took me back to the door of the temple. I saw water flowing from under the entrance of the temple toward the east. (The temple faced east.) The water was flowing under the south side of the temple, south of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he led me through the north gate and around to the outer east gate. The water was flowing down the south side of the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: With a measuring line in his hand, the man went eastward. He measured off 1,500 feet and led me through the water. The water came up to my ankles.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he measured off another 1,500 feet and led me through the water. The water came up to my knees. He measured off another 1,500 feet and led me through the water. The water came up to my waist.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he measured another 1,500 feet. But the water had risen so much that it became a river which I couldn’t cross. The river was too deep to cross except by swimming.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he asked me, “Son of man, do you see this?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man led me back along the bank of the river. As I went back, I saw many trees on both sides of the river.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man said to me, “This water flows through the land to the east, down into the Jordan Valley, and into the Dead Sea. When the water flows into the Dead Sea, it will replace the salt water there with fresh water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever the river flows, there will be many fish and animals. The river will make the water in the Dead Sea fresh. Wherever the river flows, it will bring life.
speaker: Narrator

text: From En Gedi to En Eglaim people will be standing on the shore of the sea with their fishing nets spread out. As many kinds of fish will be there as there are in the Mediterranean Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the water in the swamps and marshes won’t become fresh. It will remain salty.
speaker: Narrator

text: All kinds of fruit trees will grow on both sides of the river. Their leaves won’t wither, and they won’t fail to produce fruit. Each month they will produce fresh fruit because this water flows from the holy place. The fruit will be good food, and the leaves will be used for healing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Almighty Lord says: These are the borders of the land that is to be divided among the 12 tribes of Israel. Joseph gets two parts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Divide the land equally. I raised my hand and swore that I would give the land to your ancestors. So this land will be your inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the northern border for the land: On the north side the border will run from the Mediterranean Sea all the way to Hethlon and Hamath Pass. It will run through the city of Zedad and through
speaker: Narrator

text: Berothah and Sibraim, which are between the borders of Damascus and Hamath. It will run to Hazer Hatticon, which is on the border of Hauran.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the border will run from the Mediterranean Sea to Hazar Enon on the border of Damascus. The border of Hamath will lie to the north. This is the north side.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the east side the border will run between Hauran and Damascus. The Jordan River will serve as the border between Gilead and the land of Israel. The border will continue from the Dead Sea down to Tamar. This is the east side.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the south side the border will run from Tamar to the oasis at Meribah in Kadesh along the ravine to the Mediterranean Sea. This is the southern border.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the west side the Mediterranean Sea is the border up to a point opposite Hamath Pass. This is the west side.
speaker: Narrator

text: Divide this land among yourselves for each of the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Divide it by drawing lots. This land will be for you. It will also be for the foreign residents who live among you and have given birth to children while they lived with you. Think of them as Israelites. They will draw lots with you for their inheritance among the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Foreign residents will receive their share of the inheritance with the people of the tribe among whom they are living, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the tribes. Beginning at the northern border, Dan will have one part of the land. It will extend from the road to Hethlon to Hamath Pass and Hazar Enon, on the northern border of Damascus near Hamath, from the eastern border to the western border.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asher will have one part of the land and border Dan on the south. It will extend from the eastern border to the western border.
speaker: Narrator

text: Naphtali will have one part of the land and border Asher on the south. It will extend from the eastern border to the western border.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh will have one part of the land and border Naphtali on the south. It will extend from the eastern border to the western border.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ephraim will have one part of the land and border Manasseh on the south. It will extend from the eastern border to the western border.
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben will have one part of the land and border Ephraim on the south. It will extend from the eastern border to the western border.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah will have one part of the land and border Reuben on the south. It will extend from the eastern border to the western border.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land that you set aside as a special gift for the Lord will border Judah on the south. It will be 43,750 feet wide, and it will be as long as one of the sections of the tribes. It will extend from the eastern border to the western border, and the holy place will be in the middle of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: This special land that you set aside for the Lord will be 43,750 feet long and 17,500 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: This holy area will belong to the priests. On the north side it will be 43,750 feet long. On the west side it will be 17,500 feet wide. On the east side it will be 17,500 feet wide. On the south side it will be 43,750 feet long. The Lord’s holy place will be in the middle of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: This land that has been set apart will belong to the priests who are descendants of Zadok. They took care of my holy place. They didn’t wander away with the Israelites as the Levites did.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they will have a special portion from the land. It will be the holiest part of land, next to the land belonging to the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Alongside the land belonging to the priests will be the land belonging to the Levites. It will be 43,750 feet long and 17,500 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must not sell any of it or trade any of it. They must not let others have the best part of the land, because the land is the Lord’s and it is holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: A strip of land, 8,750 feet wide by 43,750 feet long, will be left for cities, homes, and pastures. The city will be in the middle of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: These will be the measurements for the city: On the north side it will be 7,875 feet long. On the south side it will be 7,875 feet long. On the east side it will be 7,875 feet wide. And on the west side it will be 7,875 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: The city’s pastureland will be 4,375 feet on the north, 4,375 feet on the south, 4,375 feet on the east, and 4,375 feet on the west.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the land borders the holy area and runs lengthwise. This land will be 17,500 feet on its east side and 17,500 feet on its west side. It will be used to provide food for the city workers.
speaker: Narrator

text: City workers from all the tribes in Israel will farm it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole area will be 43,750 feet square. You must give this land as a special gift to the Lord along with the city property.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever is left on the east side and west side of the holy area and the city property will belong to the prince. This land will extend eastward from the holy area to the eastern border, and it will extend westward to the western border. Both of these areas are as long as one of the sections of the tribes. These areas belong to the prince, and the holy area with the holy place of the temple will be between them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Levites’ property and the city’s property will be between the prince’s part of the land. What is between Judah’s and Benjamin’s boundaries will belong to the prince.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the rest of the tribes will receive: Benjamin will have one part of the land. It will extend from the eastern border to the western border.
speaker: Narrator

text: Simeon will have one part of the land and border Benjamin on the south. It will extend from the eastern border to the western border.
speaker: Narrator

text: Issachar will have one part of the land and border Simeon on the south. It will extend from the eastern border to the western border.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zebulun will have one part of the land and border Issachar on the south. It will extend from the eastern border to the western border.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gad will have one part of the land and border Zebulun on the south. It will extend from the eastern border to the western border.
speaker: Narrator

text: The southern border of Gad will run south from Tamar to the oasis at Meribah in Kadesh, and it will run along the Brook of Egypt to the Mediterranean Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the land you will divide as your inheritance among the tribes of Israel, and these are their areas, declares the Almighty Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: These will be the exits for the city: The north side will be 7,875 feet long.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gates of the city will be named after the tribes of Israel. The three gates on the north side will be Reuben Gate, Judah Gate, and Levi Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: The east side will be 7,875 feet long. The three gates on the east side will be Joseph Gate, Benjamin Gate, and Dan Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: The south side will be 7,875 feet long. The three gates on the south side will be Simeon Gate, Issachar Gate, and Zebulun Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: The west side will be 7,875 feet long. The three gates on the west side will be Gad Gate, Asher Gate, and Naphtali Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: The city will measure about 31,500 feet all the way around. From then on the city’s name will be: The Lord Is There.
speaker: Narrator
